{{Infobox company | name = Muñoz and Company | logo = | type = Private | genre = | foundation = 1927{{cite web|url=http://www.constructionexecutive.com/constructionemployers/Architects/35246/Kell-Munoz-Architects,-Inc..html |title=Kell Munoz Architects, Inc |publisher=Constructionexecutive.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-25}} | founder = John Kell, Sr.
Bartlett Cocke{{cite web|url=http://www.hoovers.com/company/Kell_Mu%f1oz_Architects_Inc/rtftchi-1-1njdap.html |title=Kell Muñoz Architects, Inc. | Company profile from Hoover's | 210-349-1163 |publisher=Hoovers.com |date=2010-10-21 |accessdate=2011-11-25}} | location_city = [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]] | location_country =
[[United States]] | locations = | area_served = | key_people = Henry R. Munoz III, CEO{{cite web|url=http://www.utsa.edu/today/2003/09/munoz.cfm |title=Henry Munoz to speak Oct. 1 in Frost Bank Distinguished Lecture Series > UTSA Today > University of Texas at San Antonio |publisher=Utsa.edu |date=2003-09-17 |accessdate=2011-11-25}} | industry = [[Architecture]] | products = | services = [[Architecture]], [[Interior Design|Interiors]], Graphics, Planning, Infrastructure | market cap = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.munoz-co.com/ Muñoz and Company] | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Muñoz and Company (formerly, Kell Muñoz Architects)''' is a leading{{cite news|last=Blumenthal |first=Ralph |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/04/14/us/14museum.html |title=Museum Honors Hispanic Culture - New York Times |location=San Antonio (Tex) |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=2007-04-14 |accessdate=2011-11-25}} architecture firm based in [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]], USA.{{cite web|url=http://www.architectureweek.com/directory/firms.cgi?17364 |title=Architecture Firm Listing - ArchitectureWeek Directory |publisher=Architectureweek.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-25}} Founded in 1927, the firm specializes in the design of major academic, K-12, healthcare, scientific and infrastructure projects. It is the largest minority-owned design and management firm in the state of Texas.{{cite web|url=http://americanlatinomuseum.gov/bios.html#Munoz |title=National Museum of the American Latino Commission : Commission Bios |publisher=Americanlatinomuseum.gov |date= |accessdate=2011-11-25}} Among their latest works is designing a new $150 million{{cite news|author=San Antonio Business Journal |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanantonio/stories/2009/09/14/daily28.html |title=Lake|Flato, Kell Muñoz named part of design team for U.S. Courthouse - San Antonio Business Journal |publisher=Bizjournals.com |date= 2009-09-17|accessdate=2011-11-25}} Courthouse for the City of San Antonio.{{cite web|url=https://www.fbo.gov/?s=opportunity&mode=form&id=359e78a63b9f4b532a30b366c553cb13&tab=core&_cview=1 |title=New U. S. Courthouse - Federal Business Opportunities: Opportunities |publisher=Fbo.gov |date= |accessdate=2011-11-25}} The founders were John Kell, Sr. (1903–2002) and Bartlett Cocke. Kell's mentor was [[O'Neil Ford]].{{cite web|author=David Dillon |url=http://archrecord.construction.com/projects/bts/archives/k-12/AnnRichards/overview.asp |title=Architectural Record Building Types Study | Ann Richards Middle School |publisher=Archrecord.construction.com |date=2011-10-05 |accessdate=2011-11-25}} ==Awards== Muñoz and Company has won over 130 juried design awards at the local,[https://web.archive.org/web/20110724230550/http://www.aiasa.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=113 ] state and national levels for a variety of projects.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.munoz-co.com/a/?id=2 |title=Kell Muñoz Architects |publisher=Kellmunoz.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-25}} ==Some current and recent projects== This list includes projects in which Muñoz and Company collaborated with other architecture firms:{{cite web|author=Projects project |url=http://www.munoz-co.com/projects.php?all=1 |title=Kell Muñoz Architects |publisher=Kellmunoz.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-25}} [[File:HBGConven.JPG|thumb|The [[Henry B. Gonzalez Convention Center]]]] * [[Henry B. Gonzalez Convention Center]], San Antonio, Texas * [[Dolph Briscoe Jr. Library]], [[UTHSCSA]], Texas * Northrup Hall, [[Trinity University (Texas)|Trinity University]], Texas (along with [[Robert A. M. Stern|Robert Stern]]){{cite web|author=Northrup Hall |url=http://www.munoz-co.com/project.php?project=11 |title=Kell Muñoz Architects | Northrup Hall |publisher=Kellmunoz.com |date=2005-01-01 |accessdate=2011-11-25}} * Engineering and Biotechnology Building, [[University of Texas at San Antonio|UTSA]] * [[University Health System]] Hospital * Alice McDermott Building, [[Cancer Therapy & Research Center|CTRC]], San Antonio, Texas * [[Perry Castaneda Library]], [[University of Texas at Austin|UT Austin]] * [[Our Lady of the Lake University]] main building, [[Texas]]{{cite news|author=San Antonio Business Journal |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanantonio/news/2010/11/12/our-lady-of-the-lake-to-dedicate-main.html |title=Our Lady of the Lake to dedicate Main Building - San Antonio Business Journal |publisher=Bizjournals.com |date= 2010-11-12|accessdate=2011-11-25}} * [[Frost Bank]] main tower, Downtown San Antonio, Texas * [[University of Texas at Dallas]], Math, Science and Engineering Teaching-Learning Center, Dallas, Texas[http://www.utsystem.edu/fpc/docs/CIP%20PDF/Full_CIP_at_5-13-10_Quarterly_Update.pdf FY 2010-2015 Capital Improvement Program: The University of Texas System] * [[AT&T Center]] (along with [[Ellerbe Becket]]){{cite web|author=State of Texas, University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio |url=http://www.uthscsa.edu/hscnews/singleformat2.asp?newID=1981 |title=HSC NEWS - Second building signifies expansion of HSC’s commitment to Laredo |publisher=Uthscsa.edu |date=2006-04-04 |accessdate=2011-11-25}} * [[University of Texas–Pan American]] Education Complex{{cite web|url=http://www.utpa.edu/news/index.cfm?newsid=3004 |title=News |publisher=Utpa.edu |date=2011-09-01 |accessdate=2011-11-25}} ==References== [[File:UTSA campus.jpg|thumb|[[University of Texas at San Antonio|UTSA]] Engineering Building]] {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.munoz-co.com/}} * [http://www.worldarchitecturenews.com/index.php?fuseaction=wanappln.projectview&upload_id=13484 Kell Munoz Featured on World Architecture News Magazine] * [http://texasarchitect.org/ta200709-roma.php Kell Munoz Featured by Texas Society of Architects] {{DEFAULTSORT:Kell Munoz Architects}} [[Category:Architecture firms based in Texas]] [[Category:Companies based in San Antonio]] [[Category:Design companies established in 1927]]

{{Infobox book | name = Leadville: A biography of the A140 | image = File:LeadvilleBook.jpg | border = yes | caption = First edition | author = [[Edward Platt (author)|Edward Platt]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = Gigi Sudbury
Catherine Platt | country = United Kingdom | language = English | subject = | genre = | publisher = [[Picador (imprint)|Picador]] | pub_date = 2000 | media_type = | pages = 293 | awards = [[John Llewellyn Rhys Prize]]
[[Somerset Maugham Award]] | isbn = 0-330-39262-X | oclc = | dewey = | congress = }} '''''Leadville''''' is a book by English writer [[Edward Platt (author)|Edward Platt]], published in 2000 by [[Picador (imprint)|Picador]]. It won both the [[John Llewellyn Rhys Prize]][http://www.booktrust.org.uk/jlr-archive Booktrust - John Llewellyn Prize archive] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120401030033/http://www.booktrust.org.uk/jlr-archive |date=2012-04-01 }} Retrieved 2015-04-16. and the [[Somerset Maugham Award]].[http://www.societyofauthors.org/somerset-maugham-past-winners Somerset Maugham Past Winners | Society of Authors] Retrieved 2015-04-16. Cambridge History of Science lecturer [[Patricia Fara]] selected it as one of her books of the decade.[https://bookshop.blackwell.co.uk/jsp/editorial/browse/books_of_the_decade/index_2.jsp Blackwell's Books of the Decade] Retrieved 2015-04-17. Subtitled "A Biography of the [[A40 road|A40]]" and with the strapline "A Journey from [[White City, London|White City]] to the [[Hangar Lane Gyratory]]" it tells the story of [[Western Avenue (London)|Western Avenue]], an [[arterial road]] in West [[London]] primarily through the words of its residents whom the author visited between 1995 and 1998. At this time many of the houses on the road were being [[Compulsory purchase in England and Wales|compulsorily purchased]] and demolished in preparation for a road widening scheme which was later cancelled. Interspersed with the views of the residents are historical accounts of the road's development and wider views on town planning and traffic management, prominently those of [[Le Corbusier]] and [[Robert Moses]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.theguardian.com/books/2001/may/26/nicholaslezard Nicholas Lezard finds ordinary enlightenment on the A40], review by [[Nicholas Lezard]] in ''[[The Guardian]]''. [[Category:2000 books]] [[Category:Debut books]] [[Category:Books about London]] [[Category:Books about urbanism]] [[Category:Non-fiction books about transport]] [[Category:Picador (imprint) books]] [[Category:John Llewellyn Rhys Prize-winning works]]

revision.text:
[[File:Lucia Joyce dancing at Bullier Ball - Paris, May 1929.jpg|thumb|Lucia Joyce dancing at Bullier Ball – Paris, May 1929]] '''Lucia Anna Joyce''' (26 July 1907, [[Trieste]] – 12 December 1982, [[Northampton]]) was a professional dancer and the daughter of Irish writer [[James Joyce]] and [[Nora Barnacle]]. Once treated by Swiss psychoanalyst [[Carl Jung]], Joyce was diagnosed as schizophrenic in the mid 1930s and institutionalized at the [[Burghölzli]] psychiatric clinic in [[Zurich]]. In 1951, Joyce was transferred to [[St Andrew's Hospital]] in Northampton, where she remained until her death in 1982.
==Early life and career== Lucia Anna Joyce was born in the Ospedale Civico di Trieste on 26 July 1907. She was the second child of Irish writer [[James Joyce]] and his partner (later wife) [[Nora Barnacle]], after her brother Giorgio. Her parents being expatriates living in [[Trieste]], Lucia's first language was Italian. In her younger years, she trained as a dancer at the Dalcroze Institute in Paris. Joyce studied dancing from 1925 to 1929, training first with Jacques Dalcroze, followed by [[Margaret Morris (dancer)|Margaret Morris]] (granddaughter of [[William Morris]]), and later with [[Raymond Duncan]] (brother of [[Isadora Duncan]]) at his school near Salzburg.[2] In 1927, she danced a short duet as a toy soldier in [[Jean Renoir]]’s film adaptation of Hans Christian Andersen's "La Petite marchande d’allumettes" (The Little Match Girl). She furthered her studies under Lois Hutton, Hélène Vanel, and Jean Borlin, lead dancer of the Ballet suédois.<ref>Shloss, Carol (2003). ''Lucia Joyce: To Dance in the Wake'', New York: Farrar, Straus and Girous, 140.</ref>
In 1928, she joined "Les Six de rythme et couleur," a commune of six female dancers that were soon performing at venues in France, Austria, and Germany.<ref>Le Bihan, Adrien (2011). ''James Joyce travesti par trois clercs parisiens'', Paris: Cherche Bruit, 80.</ref> After a performance in La Princesse Primitive at the Vieux-Colombier theatre, the ''Paris Times'' wrote of her, "Lucia Joyce is her father’s daughter. She has James Joyce’s enthusiasm, energy, and a not-yet-determined amount of his genius. When she reaches her full capacity for rhythmic dancing, James Joyce may yet be known as his daughter’s father."[5] <ref>Shloss, 6</ref>
On 28 May 1929, she was chosen as one of six finalists in the first international festival of dance in Paris held at the [[Bal Bullier]]. Although she did not win, the audience, which included her father and the young [[Samuel Beckett]], championed her performance as outstanding and loudly protested the jury’s verdict.<ref>Knowlson, James (1996). ''Damned to Fame: the Life of Samuel Beckett'', London: Bloomsbury, 103–104.</ref> Her relationship with [[Samuel Beckett]] was one of unrequited affection. Allegedly, when Lucia was 21, she and Beckett, who was her father's secretary for a short time, became lovers. Their relationship lasted only a short while and ended after Beckett, who was involved with another woman at the time, admitted he was solely interested in having a professional relationship with James Joyce.<ref>Shloss, 127</ref>
At the age of 22, Joyce, after years of rigorous dedication and long hours of practice, decided "she was not physically strong enough to be a dancer of any kind".<ref>[http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2003/12/08/a-fire-in-the-brain A Fire in the Brain]: The difficulties of being James Joyce’s daughter</ref> Announcing she would become a teacher, she then "turned down an offer to join a group in [[Darmstadt]] and effectively gave up dancing."<ref>[http://arlindo-correia.com/lucia_joyce.html Brenda Maddox, ''A Mania for Insects''], review of Carol Shloss’s biography, ''Lucia Joyce, To Dance in the Wake''</ref>
Her biographer Carol Shloss, however, argues that it was her father who finally put an end to her dancing career. James reasoned that the intense physical training for ballet caused her undue stress which in turn exacerbated the long-standing animosity between her and her mother Nora. The resulting incessant domestic squabbles prevented work on ''[[Finnegans Wake]]''. James convinced her she should turn to drawing [[Initial|lettrines]] to illustrate his prose and forgo her deep-seated artistic inclinations.<ref>Shloss's argument summarized in Le Bihan, 80–81.</ref> To his patron [[Harriet Shaw Weaver]], James Joyce wrote that this resulted in "a month of tears as she thinks she has thrown away three or four years of hard work and is sacrificing a talent".<ref>[http://arlindo-correia.com/lucia_joyce.html Brenda Maddox, ''A Mania for Insects'']</ref>
== Mental illness and later life == Joyce started to show signs of [[mental illness]] in 1930, a year after she began casually dating the 23-year-old [[Samuel Beckett]], then a junior lecturer in English at the [[Ecole normale supérieure]] in Paris. In May 1930, while her parents were in Zurich, she invited Beckett to dinner, hoping "to press him into some kind of declaration."<ref>Bowker, 400.</ref> He flatly rejected her, explaining that he was only interested in her father and his writing. In his biography of James Joyce, Gordon Bowker argues that the underlying reasons for the rejection were Beckett's keen awareness of the "strong unfulfilled erotic bond between Lucia and her father" and her need to find "a genius father-substitute", together with "her predilection for unprotected sex."<ref>Bowker, 400.</ref>
By 1934, she had participated in several failed affairs, with her drawing teacher [[Alexander Calder]], another expatriate artist Albert Hubbell, and Myrsine Moschos, assistant to [[Sylvia Beach]] of [[Shakespeare and Company (bookstore)|Shakespeare and Company]]. As the year wore on, her condition had deteriorated to the point that James had [[Carl Gustav Jung]] take her in as a patient. Soon after, she was diagnosed with [[schizophrenia]] at the [[Burghölzli]] psychiatric clinic in [[Zurich]]. In 1936, James consented to have his daughter undergo blood tests at [[St Andrew's Hospital]] in Northampton. After a short stay, Lucia Joyce insisted she return to Paris, the doctors explaining to her father that she could not be prevented from doing so unless he had her committed. James told his closest friends that "he would never agree to his daughter being incarcerated among the English."<ref>Bowker, 482.</ref>
Lucia Joyce returned to stay with [[Maria Jolas]], the wife of ''[[transition (literary journal)|transition]]'' editor [[Eugene Jolas]], in [[Neuilly-sur-Seine]]. After three weeks, her condition worsened and she was taken away in a [[straitjacket]] to the Maison de Santé Velpeau in [[Vésinet]]. Considered a danger to both staff and inmates, she was left in isolation. Two months later, she entered the ''maison de santé'' of François Achille Delmas at [[Ivry-sur-Seine]].<ref>Bowker, 482.</ref>
In 1951, Joyce was again transferred to St Andrew's Hospital. Over the years, she received visits from Beckett, [[Sylvia Beach]], [[Frank Budgen]], Maria Jolas, and Harriet Shaw Weaver who acted as her guardian. In 1962, Beckett donated his share of the royalties from his 1929 contributory essay on ''Finnegans Wake'' in ''[[Our Exagmination Round His Factification for Incamination of Work in Progress]]'' to help pay for her confinement at St Andrew's.<ref>Bair, Deirdre (1980). ''Samuel Beckett: A Biography'', London: Picador, 451.</ref>
In 1982, Joyce suffered a stroke and died on 12 December of that year.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Beja|first1=Morris|title=James Joyce: A Literary Life|date=1992|publisher=Ohio State University Press|location=Columbus, Ohio|page=125}}</ref> She is buried in [[Kingsthorpe]] Cemetery.
== Legacy == Her mental state, and documentation related to it, is the subject of a 2003 study by Carol Shloss who believes Lucia Joyce to have been her father's [[muse]] for ''[[Finnegans Wake]]''. Making heavy reference to the letters between Joyce and her father, the study became the subject of a [[copyright misuse]] suit by the James Joyce estate. On 25 March 2007, this litigation was resolved.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/6493095.stm Joyce letters court case settled]. B.B.C., 2007-03-25.</ref><ref>[https://swap.stanford.edu/20080725075557/http://www.firstamendmentcenter.org/news.aspx?id=18335 Scholar, James Joyce estate settle copyright dispute]. First Amendment Center/Associated Press, 2007-03-27.{{Dead link|date=October 2016}}</ref>
In 2004, Joyce's life was the subject of ''Calico'', a West End play written by [[Michael Hastings (playwright)|Michael Hastings]], and of the 2012 graphic novel ''[[Dotter of Her Father's Eyes]]'' by Bryan and Mary M. Talbot.<ref>{{cite news |first=Rachel |last=Cooke |title=Dotter of Her Father's Eyes by Mary M Talbot and Bryan Talbot – review |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/jan/27/dotter-fathers-eyes-talbot-james-joyce |work=The Guardian |date=27 January 2012 |accessdate=3 August 2015}}</ref> Another play exploring her life titled ''L'' was performed to a limited audience in Concord Academy from April 14–16, 2016. It was written and directed by Sophia Ginzburg.<ref>http://www.concordacademy.org/news/detail/index.aspx?LinkId=5507&ModuleId=280,485{{Dead link|date=October 2016}}</ref> In 2016, she was the subject of a biographical novel, ''The Joyce Girl'' by [[Annabel Abbs]], which was published in the UK, Ireland, Australia and New Zealand and translated into German, Spanish and Turkish. She is the protagonist of the "Round the Bend" chapter of [[Alan Moore]]'s 2016 novel ''Jerusalem''; set at the Northampton clinic where she spent her final years, the chapter is written in the style of her father's ''Finnegans Wake''.
==References== ===Notes=== {{reflist}}
===Bibliography=== <div style="font-size: 95%">
* Patry, William (2006), "[http://williampatry.blogspot.com/2006/06/copyrights-wake.html The Patry Copyright Blog: Copyright's Wake]" (concerning research done on Lucia as Joyce's muse). Retrieved 28 August 2015 * Shloss, Carol Loeb. ''Lucia Joyce: To Dance in the Wake''. Farrar, Straus, and Girous, New York, 2003. {{ISBN|0-374-19424-6}}
==External links== * [http://www.arlindo-correia.org/140504.html Lucia Joyce]. Collection of articles and reviews. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080322164109/http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/03/24/arts/NA-A-E-BKS-US-James-Joyce-Lawsuit.php Resolution of the litigation]. Retrieved December 9, 2007.
{{James Joyce}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Joyce, Lucia}} [[Category:1907 births]] [[Category:1982 deaths]] [[Category:People associated with James Joyce]] [[Category:History of mental health in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:People with schizophrenia]]

revision.comment: added [[Category:Renaissance architecture]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=June 2016}} {{noref|date=June 2016}} }}
'''Maashaus''' ({{lang-de|Maßhaus}}) is a spacious room taking the whole front part of a ground floor of a multi-storied [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] or [[Renaissance architecture|Renaissance]] town house.
This room was used mainly for serving beer, or other kinds of trade and craft. It was not heated. It also worked to link together other parts of the house, since it held a staircase to the first floor above ground (where the owner lived) and to the basement, an archway or similar passage to the courtyard and so on. The ceiling was almost always [[Vault (architecture)|vaulted]] and was often supported by an asymmetrically placed central [[column]]. It was separated from the street or the arcade by a wall with a doorway and one or more windows.
==Origins==
Maashauses started to appear in the 13th century as a manifestation of the trend to sequester the living quarters of a burgers' house to the first floor. What used to be a main living room of the house, the so-called smoke abode, kept only its public, trade and craft functions, which remained on the ground floor, because they required the proximity of the cellar, the courtyard and especially the street entrance. The trade activities involved mainly the aforementioned serving of beer, which is related to the [[brewing right]]s (in the [[Middle Ages]] a vast majority of burgers' houses were granted this right), but other trade and crafts were performed there also.
==Maashauses in Bohemia==
In the 19th century most maashauses were converted to private shops. Later, they were being renovated in many historic cities as part of restoration activities in the [[History of Czechoslovakia (1948–89)|socialist period]]. To this day, maashauses are found in many buildings in the centers of [[Český Krumlov|Česky Krumlov]], [[Slavonice]] and so on. After 1989 many maashauses were again employed for retail or by pubs and restaurants.
==Etymology== "[[Maß]]“ is an old unit of volume (approximately equivalent to 1.4 [[Litre|l]]), used for measuring mainly [[beer]], ''haus'' means a "house“ in German, but in the past it could also stand for the main living room of a house. Therefore, maashaus could be translated as a "beer house".
[[Category:Rooms]] [[Category:Architecture articles needing attention]] [[Category:Cultural history]] [[Category:Brewing]] [[Category:Renaissance architecture]]

{{Distinguish|Truth or Dare by Madonna}} {{Infobox film | name = Madonna: Truth or Dare | image = Madonna truth or dare poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Alek Keshishian]] | producer = [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]
[[Tim Clawson]]
[[Steve Golin]]
Lisa Hollingshead
Daniel Radford
Jay Roewe
[[Sigurjón Sighvatsson]] | narrator = Madonna | starring = Madonna | music = Madonna | cinematography = Christophe Lanzeburg
Robert Leacock
[[Doug Nichol]]
[[Daniel Pearl (cinematographer)|Daniel Pearl]]
Toby Phillips
Marc Reshovsky | editing = [[Barry Alexander Brown]] | studio = Boy Toy, Inc.
[[Propaganda Films]] | distributor = [[Miramax Films]] | released = {{film date|1991|5|10}} (limited release)
{{Film date|1991|5|24}}(wide release) | runtime = 122 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $4.5 million | gross = $29,012,935 }} '''''Madonna: Truth or Dare''''' (known as '''''In Bed with Madonna''''' outside of North America) is a 1991 American [[documentary film]] chronicling the life of [[United States|American]] singer and songwriter [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] during her 1990 [[Blond Ambition World Tour]]. The film was generally well received by critics and was successful at the box office with a worldwide gross of $29,012,935 (an estimated ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|29|r=2|1991}}}} million in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}). It remained the highest-grossing documentary of all time, until ''[[Bowling for Columbine]]'' surpassed it in 2002.http://articles.latimes.com/2003/jan/03/entertainment/et-munoz3/2 It was screened out of competition at the [[1991 Cannes Film Festival]].{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/94/year/1991.html |title=Festival de Cannes: Truth or Dare |accessdate=2009-08-12|publisher=festival-cannes.com}} In 2005, Madonna produced another documentary, ''[[I'm Going to Tell You a Secret]]'', which followed her 2004 [[Re-Invention World Tour]]. It was filmed and narrated in the same style as ''Truth or Dare'', with stage performances filmed in colour and behind-the-scenes in black and white. ''Truth or Dare'' was nominated for a [[Razzie Award]] for Worst Actress for Madonna as herself, which she lost to [[Sean Young]] for ''[[A Kiss Before Dying (1991 film)|A Kiss Before Dying]]''.{{cite book|last=Wilson|first=John|title=The Official Razzie Movie Guide: Enjoying the Best of Hollywood's Worst |year=2005|publisher=Grand Central Publishing|isbn=0-446-69334-0}} It holds an 84% rating on [[Rotten Tomatoes]] based on 25 reviews.{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/madonna_truth_or_dare/|title=Madonna: Truth or Dare|work=rottentomatoes.com|accessdate=12 January 2017}} ==Plot== {{Long plot|film|date=August 2018}} The film begins on August 6, 1990, the day after the final show of the [[Blond Ambition Tour]] in [[Nice]]. [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] cleans up her hotel room while, in a [[voice-over]], she explains that she is not as emotional as the rest of her group over the end of the tour. She has already grieved, she says, but it will hit her later and she hopes she will be in a safe place when it happens. In a flashback to April 1990, the tour is about to kick off in Japan. Everything is a mess; there are sound problems and Madonna did not realize that the tour is during the [[rainy season]] in Japan. Because it is cold and wet, Madonna and the dancers scrap their costumes for warmer attire. In a voice-over, Madonna confesses that the only thing keeping her from "slashing my wrists" is the thought of returning to [[North America]] and performing the show as it is meant to be. In America, Madonna meets the families of her dancers. One dancer, Oliver, sees his father for the first time in several years, while Madonna talks with her father, Silvio "Tony" Ciccone, on the phone. Though she insists that she can get him tickets, he is reluctant to impose. The Blond Ambition tour stops in [[Los Angeles]], where sound problems abound. Despite reassurances, Madonna focuses on the technical problems and yells at her manager, [[Freddy DeMann]], for allowing so many people from the music industry, who appeared bored by her performance, in the front rows. Though then-boyfriend [[Warren Beatty]] tries to console her, he is distracted by the cameras and walks away laughing. Madonna parties with several celebrities, including ''[[Dick Tracy (1990 film)|Dick Tracy]]'' co-stars [[Al Pacino]] and [[Mandy Patinkin]], and [[Olivia Newton-John]]. [[Kevin Costner]] offends Madonna by calling her show "neat". Madonna pretends to gag after he leaves. Despite the lively atmosphere, Beatty still seems bothered by the cameras' presence. During her stay in Washington, D.C., Madonna attends the premiere of ''Dick Tracy'' with Beatty, with whom she co-starred. In another voice-over, she describes a dream that she had the night before: [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] came to her show and she thought about how jealous Beatty would be that she met him first. She declares it "a good dream". On the final night of the show in [[Toronto]], Madonna is informed that [[Undercover operation#Plainclothes law enforcement|plainclothes]] officers are prepared to arrest her if she performs the simulated [[masturbation]] scene at the end of "[[Like a Virgin (song)|Like a Virgin]]". Madonna refuses to change her show, stating, "Last time I was on tour, [[Sean Penn|Sean]] [Penn] was in jail. I guess it's my turn." Freddy DeMann bets that the threat of arrest will only make Madonna go further and no one takes his bet. According to a news report, Toronto police decide not to arrest the singer, claiming that no threats were made. The Blond Ambition tour goes to Madonna's hometown of [[Detroit]]. In a voice-over, Madonna expresses the difficulty she has going back home, especially since fame seems to change one's loved ones. At the end of "[[Holiday (Madonna song)|Holiday]]", Madonna calls her father on stage and sings "[[Happy Birthday to You]]". Backstage, Tony and his wife, Joan, compliment Madonna (and Christopher) on the show, though Tony expresses his displeasure at some of the more "burlesque" aspects. Madonna and Christopher wait for their older brother, Martin, to show up while they discuss his substance abuse problems. By the time Martin arrives, Christopher has left and Madonna has gone to bed. Madonna reunites with her "childhood idol", Moira McFarland-Messana. Moira gives Madonna a painting she made entitled "Madonna and Child", and asks Madonna to be the godmother to her unborn child. Before leaving Detroit, Madonna visits her mother's grave as "Promise to Try" plays in the background. It is the first time she has visited her mother's grave since she was a little girl. Madonna lies down beside her mother's grave as Christopher watches and Madonna whispers that, "I'm going to fit in right here. They're going to bury me sideways." As the tour continues, Madonna's throat problems worsen while Beatty becomes more fed up with the cameras. During a throat examination in Madonna's hotel room, Beatty chastises her for the documentary, telling her the atmosphere is driving everyone insane. Madonna ignores Beatty, and when she declines to have the rest of her examination done off camera, Beatty starts laughing, saying, "She doesn't want to live off-camera, much less talk... What point is there of existing off-camera?" Due to Madonna's throat problems she cancels some of her shows. In [[New York City|New York]], Madonna's doctor instructs her not to talk and she finds herself isolated in her apartment with only her assistant, Melissa Crowe, as contact to the outside world. Everything seems to fall apart and she loses contact with the dancers. ''[[Star (magazine)|Star]]'' reports that Madonna dumped Beatty for one of her dancers, Oliver Crumes. The other dancers torment him and Madonna chastises them. Sharon Gault, a make-up artist, is drugged and [[sodomy|sodomized]] while partying. In a prayer circle before the final show in New York, Madonna attempts to pull everyone back together. The third leg of the tour kicks off in [[Europe]] with everyone in better spirits. Madonna and the dancers visit [[Chanel]] in [[Paris]], fool around at Melissa's birthday party and imitate Madonna's 1984 "Like a Virgin" music video. As the tour nears Italy, the [[Pope]] attempts to have it banned, forcing Madonna to cancel two shows. [[Sandra Bernhard]] appears to cheer up Madonna. Sandra asks who would really blow her away if she could meet them and Madonna replies, "God, I think I've met everybody... oh, except that guy who's in all of [[Pedro Almodóvar]]'s films—[[Antonio Banderas]]." When Almodóvar throws a party in [[Madrid]] and invites the future ''[[Evita (1996 film)|Evita]]'' co-stars, Madonna spends a week thinking up ways to seduce Banderas. It turns out that he is married, ending Madonna's two-year crush. While Madonna works in her hotel room, voice-overs from her family, friends, and co-workers describe the star. Though she is happier now than she was on her [[Who's That Girl Tour|last tour]], Sandra Bernhard does not think that she takes enough time to enjoy her successes. Others describe her in unflattering terms. Luis Camacho says, "I just feel like she's a little girl lost in the storm sometimes. You know, there's just a whole whirlwind of things going on around her, and sometimes she gets caught up in it." As the tour winds down, the group plays a game of [[Truth or Dare?]] and Madonna is dared to perform [[Fellatio]] on a glass bottle. Madonna is asked, "Who has been the love of your life for your whole life??" Madonna replies without hesitation, "[[Sean Penn|Sean]]. Sean." Madonna invites her dancers, and backup singers, one-by-one, to join her in bed, where she imparts words of wisdom to each. While the show's closing act, "[[Keep It Together (Madonna song)|Keep It Together]]", plays, a montage of Madonna saying good-bye to her dancers is shown. The film ends with a clip of Madonna telling director [[Alek Keshishian]] to go away and, "Cut it, Alek! Cut it, Goddamnit!" ==Cast== * [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] ; Uncredited {{Cast listing| * [[Warren Beatty]] * [[Antonio Banderas]] * [[Sandra Bernhard]] * [[Pedro Almodóvar]] * [[Olivia Newton-John]] * [[Matt Dillon]] * [[Kevin Costner]] * [[Lionel Richie]] * [[Mandy Patinkin]] * [[Al Pacino]] * [[Freddy DeMann]] }} ==History== The title of the documentary is in reference to the party game [[Truth or Dare?]] Outside [[North America]] the documentary title was changed by [[Miramax]] Films to ''In Bed with Madonna'', due to the game being relatively unknown in other countries. Madonna has commented in various interviews that she hates the title of ''In Bed with Madonna''.{{cite interview |subject=Madonna |subjectlink=Madonna (entertainer) |interviewer=[[Dermot O'Leary]] |title=Confessions of Madonna |publisher=[[Channel 4]] |location=London |date=November 27, 2005 |quote= [...] as a kind of sequel to ''Truth or Dare'' or I think it was called ''In Bed with Madonna'', which is a really naff title. It wasn't my idea.}} The original working title of the documentary was ''"Truth or Dare: On the Road, Behind the Scenes and In Bed with Madonna"''. During the summer of 1990, Madonna hired director [[Alek Keshishian]] to film backstage and onstage footage of her [[Blond Ambition World Tour]]. The entire documentary is filmed in [[black-and-white]], except for onstage sequences which are in full color. There are appearances from celebrities such as [[Al Pacino]], [[Mandy Patinkin]], [[Olivia Newton-John]], [[Antonio Banderas]], [[Sandra Bernhard]], [[Kevin Costner]], and [[Warren Beatty]], whom she was dating at the time. Concert video footage was shot at [[Palais Omnisports de Paris-Bercy|Bercy]] in [[Paris]], [[France]], in July 1990. In the "[[Express Yourself (Madonna song)|Express Yourself]]" concert sequence, Madonna says "All right, America! Do you believe in love?" This audio is overdubbed from a US date onto footage shot in Paris where she does not wear the ponytail as in the Japan and USA stops. ==In popular media== To promote the just-released film, Madonna made a guest appearance in a pre-filmed segment on the May 11, 1991 episode of the sketch-comedy show ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''. During a ''[[Wayne's World]]'' sketch, Wayne ([[Mike Myers (actor)|Mike Myers]]) and Garth ([[Dana Carvey]]) encounter a seductive Madonna lying on a bed in a hotel room during a dream fantasy sequence (filmed in black and white). After some back-and-forth banter, Wayne and Madonna play [[Truth or Dare]]. Wayne dares Madonna to make out with him. As they kiss, the music for her controversial 1990 video "[[Justify My Love]]" begins to play. Garth is then seen dancing in a parody of the video before being abducted by two women in fetish-wear outfits. The [[parody]], ''[[Medusa: Dare to Be Truthful]]'', stars comedian [[Julie Brown]] as the title character, with [[Kathy Griffin]] and [[Donal Logue]] in supporting roles. Brown plays [[Medusa]], a controlling, hyper-sexual blonde bombshell who has allowed a documentary crew to follow her on her "Blonde Leading the Blonde Tour". The film, originally produced as a one-hour [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] television special, goes to great pains to recreate costumes, sets, and situations that occurred in the original documentary. Rock group [[Medusa (band)|Medusa]] released the documentary "In Bed with Medusa" in 2013.[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2756008/] In Bed with Medusa (2013) IMDb IMDb.com. Retrieved 2013-04-01 The film uses the same black and white style along with many further references as it simultaneously parodies the film and documents the early life of the band as they release 2 albums and hit the headlines in the UK. In addition, the popular British television comedy programme ''[[French & Saunders]]'' did a highly regarded parody of the film with both stars playing Madonna in tandem, a unique concept, which was called "In Bed with French & Saunders". Madonna herself was widely reported to be delighted with the long skit, saying that when French & Saunders did a parody of anything, it was proof that it had "arrived". In 2016, ''[[Strike a Pose]]'', a documentary about the life and career of Madonna's dancers over 20 years after the [[Blond Ambition World Tour]], was released. They look back on the impact of that tour and tour film on people's lives, and what was happening in the background on emotional levels. ==Lawsuit== On January 21, 1992, three of the Blond Ambition dancers, Oliver Crumes, [[Kevin Stea]], and Gabriel Trupin, filed a lawsuit against Madonna. The suit claimed that the singer had invaded her dancers' privacy during the filming of ''Truth or Dare'', as well as charging her with fraud and deceit, intentional misrepresentation, suppression of fact, and intentional infliction of emotional distress for displaying the men's private lives in the documentary. In a commercial for MTV's [[Rock the Vote]] campaign later that year, Madonna joked about the lawsuit, saying, "You're probably thinking that's not a very good reason to vote... So sue me! Everybody else does." In October 1994, after more than two years of litigation, the suit was withdrawn and an undisclosed settlement was reached.[http://articles.courant.com/1994-10-02/entertainment/9409300079_1_madonna-gabriel-trupin-oliver-crumesaid=380&category=Hartford Courant] Dancers Settle Suit Against Madonna, October 02, 1994 == Reactions on showing gay people == Madonna's dancers for the tour, who were almost all gay, and showed their homosexual identity in the tour film (encouraged by Madonna to be and 'express themselves'), received numerous comments, messages and letters from fans to whom this freedom meant a great deal as role models and inspiration to live their own sexual identity. This impact was mentioned in the 2016 documentary [[Strike a Pose]]. During media interviews for ''Strike a Pose'', a documentary about Madonna's dancers from the Blond Ambition tour, and featured in this film, Oliver Crumes frequently expressed regret for his homophobic comments in the film.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cswap.com/1991/Madonna:_Truth_or_Dare/cap/en/25fps/a/01_40|title=Madonna: Truth or Dare - 01:40|website=www.cswap.com|language=en|access-date=2017-03-10}}{{Cite web|url=https://squaremadonna.com/2016/04/07/oliver-crumes-the-tour-taught-me-to-appreciate-gay-people/|title=OLIVER CRUMES : ‘THE TOUR TAUGHT ME TO APPRECIATE GAY PEOPLE’|date=2016-04-07|website=squaremadonna|access-date=2017-03-10}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.calgaryherald.com/entertainment/strike+pose+revisits+madonnas+blond+ambition+tour+dancers/13075428/story.html|title=Q&A: 'Strike a Pose' doc revisits Madonna's Blond Ambition tour dancers|last=Friend|first=David|date=March 9, 2017|work=Calgary Herald/The Canadian Press|access-date=March 10, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} "I have come to see we are all human beings, who have emotions, hearts and feelings. The only thing that makes us different is our choice of different or same genders to love," he said in an interview with The Canadian Press, reading from a statement written with the help of his wife. He would repeat similar comments against violence towards people in the LGBTQ community in other interviews, and emphasize that his outlook has changed since the tour. ==Video release== {{Infobox album | name = Madonna: Truth or Dare | type = Video | artist = [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] | cover = | border = yes | alt = | caption = Blu-ray version of the film, released in 2012 | released = October 7, 1991 | recorded = 1990 | venue = | studio = | genre = Documentary/Live | length = 122 minutes | label = LIVE Home Video | producer = | chronology = [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] video | prev_title = [[Blond Ambition World Tour Live]] | prev_year = 1990 | next_title = [[The Girlie Show: Live Down Under]] | next_year = 1994 }} The film was released on home video by [[Artisan Entertainment|LIVE Entertainment]] in [[North America]] on October 9, 1991.{{cite AV media notes |title=Madonna:Truth or Dare|others=Madonna|year=1991|publisher=LIVE Entertainment|id=68976}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tower.com/madonna-truth-or-dare-laserdisc/wapi/107545428 |title=Laserdisc: Madonna - Truth or Dare (Widescreen Edition) [VHS] (Laserdisc) with Madonna (actor), Warren Beatty (actor) and Alek Keshishian (director) |publisher=Tower.com |date=1991-10-09 |accessdate=2012-07-24}} Outside of North America it was released as ''In Bed with Madonna''. In the UK an additional VHS "[[British Board of Film Classification#Current certificates|15]]" certificate, edited version was released in November 1991, to allow younger teenagers to watch it.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/BVF063175/ |title=Title « British Board of Film Classification |publisher=Bbfc.co.uk |accessdate=2012-07-24}} The packaging was slightly changed to a 'blue' format otherwise identical to the original. In 1992, it was re-released on VHS in the US with two additional live videos of "Like a Prayer" and "Hanky Panky", which played after the end credits.{{cite AV media notes |title=Madonna:Truth or Dare|others=Madonna|year=1991|publisher=LIVE Entertainment|id=69021}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tower.com/madonna-truth-or-dare-vhs/wapi/105984978 |title=Music: Madonna - Truth or Dare (VHS) by Madonna (Artist) |publisher=Tower.com |date=1992-07-15 |accessdate=2012-07-24}} The [[DVD]] version was released on August 26, 1997 by LIVE Entertainment in [[North America]] but did not get a worldwide DVD release until January 6, 2003 by [[MGM]] Entertainment.{{cite web|last=Goosey |first=Gareth |url=http://www.lovefilm.com/film/Madonna-In-Bed-With-Madonna/7298/ |title=Madonna - In Bed With Madonna DVD (1991) |publisher=Lovefilm |accessdate=2012-07-24}} In March 2009, a new HD master of the film premiered on Palladia HD ([[MTV]]'s new name). It included the new Miramax logo at the beginning of the film and a [[Warner Bros. Television]] logo at its closing.{{cite web|url=http://www.palladia.tv/schedule.php |title=TV Schedule | High definition music television |publisher=Palladia.tv |accessdate=2012-07-24}} The [[blu-ray disc|Blu-ray]] version of the film, along with a new DVD release, which is a reprint to the 1997 release, was released by [[Lionsgate]] in North America on April 3, 2012.{{cite web|url=http://bluray.highdefdigest.com/news/show/Disc_Announcements/Lionsgate/Madonna_Truth_or_Dare_Blu-ray_Dated_and_Detailed/8658 |title='Madonna: Truth or Dare' Blu-ray Dated and Detailed | High-Def Digest |publisher=Bluray.highdefdigest.com |date=2012-02-01 |accessdate=2012-07-24}} The typography for the new release was changed from the original design and is similar to the fashion brand and perfume, ''[[Truth or Dare by Madonna]]'' which was released at the same time. ===Track listing=== ;Concert footage includes *"[[Express Yourself (Madonna song)|Express Yourself]]" *"[[Oh Father]]" *"[[Like a Virgin (song)|Like a Virgin]]" *"Promise to Try" (montage of film, not concert performance) *"[[Holiday (Madonna song)|Holiday]]" *"[[Live to Tell]]" *"[[Vogue (Madonna song)|Vogue]]" *"[[Family Affair (Sly and the Family Stone song)|Family Affair]]"/"[[Keep It Together (Madonna song)|Keep It Together]]" ;plus excerpts from *"[[Papa Don't Preach]]" (during soundcheck) *"[[Like a Prayer (song)|Like a Prayer]]" *"[[Causing a Commotion]]" ;US special edition VHS additional footage *"Like a Prayer" *"[[Hanky Panky (Madonna song)|Hanky Panky]]" ;''Madonna: Truth or Dare'' DVD extras *Original theatrical trailer *Production notes *Cast and crew biographies ;''In Bed with Madonna'' DVD extras/''Madonna: Truth or Dare'' Blu-ray extras *Original theatrical trailer ===Formats=== *[[VHS]] (1991) – International release *''In Bed with Madonna'' - VHS "[[British Board of Film Classification#Current certificates|15]]" certificate version (1991) – released only in the UK, running time was 114 minutes, edited to allow younger viewers to watch the film. Released by [[2 Entertain|Video Collection International]]. *[[Laserdisc]] (1991) – released in the US *''In Bed with Madonna'' - Laserdisc (1993) – released outside the US *VHS (1992) – re-released in the US with additional concert footage of "Like a Prayer" and "Hanky Panky" shown after the ending credits, duration is 133 minutes *[[DVD]] (1997) – released in North America only *''In Bed with Madonna'' - [[VCD]] (1997) – released in Asian countries only *''In Bed with Madonna'' - DVD (2003) – released worldwide outside the US and Canada, this was the first DVD release internationally by [[MGM Home Entertainment]]. *[[Blu-ray]] (2012) – released only in the US *Blu-ray + DVD combo (2012) – released only in Canada, contains both discs, DVD contains the same 1997 release *''In Bed with Madonna'' - Blu-ray and DVD (2018), released in August 2018 to commemorate Madonna's 60th Birthday and released by [[MGM]] and [[Koch Media]], exclusively in Germany ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0102370}} * {{Mojo title|truthordare}} {{Madonna}} [[Category:1991 films]] [[Category:1991 video albums]] [[Category:1990s LGBT-related films]] [[Category:American documentary films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American LGBT-related films]] [[Category:Concert films]] [[Category:Documentary films about singers]] [[Category:Documentary films about women]] [[Category:Films directed by Alek Keshishian]] [[Category:Live video albums]] [[Category:Madonna (entertainer) video albums]] [[Category:Black-and-white documentary films]] [[Category:Directorial debut films]] [[Category:Films produced by Steve Golin]] [[Category:American black-and-white films]] [[Category:Koch Media]]

revision.comment: fixed [[MOS:DASH|dashes]] using a [[User:GregU/dashes.js|script]]
revision.text:
The '''Manchester Academy of Fine Arts''' ('''MAFA''') is a society established in 1859 to organise annual open exhibitions in [[Manchester City Art Gallery]], formerly the Manchester Institution. Since the refurbishment of the [[art gallery]], MAFA has endeavoured to maintain its profile by presenting [[art exhibition|exhibitions]] of [[painting]], [[Printmaking|prints]], [[drawing]]s and [[sculpture]] in venues in [[Manchester]] and throughout [[North West England]].
The society has been associated with a number of notable individuals, including [[Alfred Waterhouse]], [[Ford Madox Brown]], [[LS Lowry]], [[Käthe Schuftan]], [[Norman Adams (British artist)|Norman Adams]] and Anne Redpath. Past presidents include the artists [[William Knight Keeling]], [[Charles Oppenheimer]] and [[Robert Crozier (artist)|Robert Crozier]].<ref name=MAFA>[http://www.mafa.org.uk/past_presidents.php "History of Mafa: Past Presidents"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160302044715/http://www.mafa.org.uk/past_presidents.php |date=2016-03-02 }}, ''Manchester Academy of Fine Arts'' website, accessed 11 November 2009</ref> Academy members have played a significant role in the Manchester art scene for over a century, including the design of several of its buildings and public works.
==Membership==
The academy consists of more than 100 elected members who are mainly professional artists practising not only in the North West of England but throughout the United Kingdom and in Europe. The objective of the academy is to promote the work of its members and other artists by organising exhibitions, workshops and talks.
In 2009–2010, MAFA celebrated its 150th anniversary through a series of exhibitions and a service at [[Manchester Cathedral]] in November 2009.
==References== {{reflist}}
*Davies, Peter (1989), ''A Northern School'', Redcliffe Press, Bristol *Dewsbury, S. and Adams, A.C., ''The Story So Far: The Manchester Academy of Fine Arts 1859–2003'' *Wyke, Terry (2004), ''Public Sculpture in Greater Manchester'', Liverpool University Press *Nairne, Sandy and Howgate, Sarah (15 March 2006), ''The Portrait Now'', Yale University Press *Marks, Diana F. (2006), ''Children's Book Award Handbook'', Libraries Unlimited (Chapter 6 on [[Randolph Caldecott]] and the [[Caldecott Medal|Randolph Caldecott Medal]]) *Thomson, Susan W (2007), ''Manchester's Victorian Art Scene and Its Unrecognised Artists'', Manchester Art Press *Buckman, David (17 September 2003), "Tom Titherington: Obit.", ''The Independent''
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.mafa.org.uk}}

revision.comment: [[Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]: Copying from [[Category:20th-century American sculptors]] to [[Category:American male sculptors]]
revision.text:
[[File:Max Kalish Smithsonian J0020817.jpg|thumb|Max Kalish]] '''Max Kalish''' (March 1, 1891 – 1945) was American sculptor born in [[Valozhyn]], [[Belarus]], and best known for his sculptures of laborers.
His Orthodox Jewish family emigrated to Cleveland, Ohio in 1893, when he was two years old.<ref>http://americanart.si.edu/collections/search/artist/?id=2534</ref>
He studied with [[Herman Matzen]] at the [[Cleveland School of Art]]; in New York City with [[Herbert Adams (sculptor)|Herbert Adams]] at the National Academy of Design, and in the studios of [[Alexander Stirling Calder]] and [[Isidore Konti]]; and in Paris with [[Paul Wayland Bartlett]] at the Académie Colorossi, and [[Jean Antoine Injalbert]] at the [[École des Beaux-Arts]].<ref>Opitz, Glenn B, editor, ''Mantle Fielding's Dictionary of American Painters, Sculptors & Engravers'', Apollo Book, Poughkeepsie NY, 1986</ref><ref name="Who">McGlauflin, Alice Coe, editor, ''Who’s Who in American Art 1938-1939, vol. 2'', The American Federation of Arts, Washington D.C., 1937</ref><ref>http://americanart.si.edu/collections/search/artist/?id=2534</ref>
His best known work is his 1932 statue of Abraham Lincoln in Cleveland, Ohio.
Washington, D.C. publisher Willard M. Kiplinger commissioned Kalish to create fifty portrait statuettes of prominent figures in World War II era politics, arts and sciences. Kiplinger donated the statuettes to the [[Smithsonian Institution]] in 1944.<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=14E616B32D504.1375&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!453060~!36&ri=1&aspect=Browse&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=Kalish,+Max,+1891-1945,+sculptor.&index=AUTHOR&uindex=&aspect=Browse&menu=search&ri=1 Walter Lippmann], from Smithsonian Institution.</ref>
Kalish was the author of ''Labor Sculpture'', largely a collection of photographs of his statues of workers. Most of the works in the book are in a [[Social realism]] style. Critic Emily Genauer wrote in 1938, "It is the workmen who dominate the American scene, and who have become as surely symbolic of their time as the pioneers in covered wagons, and the robber barons and the great merchant princes were in there respective eras." This was what Kalish portrayed in his art.<ref>Kalish, Max, ''Labor Sculpture'', Introduction by Emily Genauer, New York, 1938, copyright by Max Kalish, introduction</ref>
In 1939, Kalish lived in New York City and summered in Cleveland.<ref name="Who"/>
==Works== Examples of Kalish’s work can be found in:<ref>http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=1466S1249K910.247&profile=ariall&uri=link=3100006~!201624~!3100001~!3100002&aspect=Browse&menu=search&ri=1&source=~!siartinventories&term=Kalish%2C+Max%2C+1891-1945%2C+sculptor.&index=AUTHOR</ref> * ''Baby’s Head'', Canajoharie Library and Art Gallery, [[Canajoharie, New York]] * ''Old Man Resting'', Massillon Museum, [[Massillon, Ohio]] * ''Portrait of a Boy'', [[North Carolina Museum of Art]], [[Raleigh, North Carolina]] * ''Gold Prospector'', [[Canton Museum of Art]], [[Canton, Ohio]] * ''Head of [[Louis Kronberg]]'', [[Museum of Fine Arts, Boston|Museum of Fine Arts]], [[Boston, Massachusetts]] * ''Torso,'' [[Washington County Museum of Fine Arts]], [[Hagerstown, Maryland]] * ''Laborer at Rest'', [[Newark Museum]], [[Newark, New Jersey]] * ''Torso'' (1925), [[Cleveland Museum of Art]], [[Cleveland, Ohio]] * ''The End of Day'' (1930), Smithsonian American Art Museum, [[Washington, D.C.]] * ''Abraham Lincoln'' (1927-32), Board of Education, Cleveland, Ohio * ''Man of Steel'' (before 1933), [[Smithsonian American Art Museum]], Washington, D.C.
<gallery> File:End of the Day by Max Kalish Smithsonian1933.1.2.jpg|''The End of Day'' (1930), Smithsonian American Art Museum. File:Abraham Lincoln by Max Kalish - Cleveland Municipal School District Headquarters - DSC07950.JPG|''Abraham Lincoln'' (1927-32), Cleveland Municipal School District Headquarters. File:Man of Steel by Max Kalish 1933 Smithsonian.jpg|''Man of Steel'' (before 1933), Smithsonian American Art Museum. </gallery>
==References== {{reflist}} {{commonscat}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kalish, Max}}

page.title: Metropolitan Zoological Park and Museum District

revision.comment: /* External links */
revision.text:
The '''Metropolitan Zoological Park and Museum District''' or '''ZMD''' is a cultural tax district in [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis City]] and [[St. Louis County, Missouri]]. The district has five subdistricts, these being the [[St. Louis Art Museum]], [[St. Louis Zoo]], [[St. Louis Science Center]], [[Missouri History Museum]], and [[Missouri Botanical Garden]]. Of these, all but the Botanical Gardens are located in or near [[Forest Park (St. Louis)|Forest Park]]. The subsidies provided by the district ensures that the institutions are public non-profits with free admission for all, with the exception of the Botanical Gardens, which charges a nominal admission fee.
==History== In the early 1960s, the St. Louis Art Museum and the St. Louis Zoo were both publicly funded by a tax in St. Louis City. Zoo chairman [[Howard Baer]] and his successor, Circuit Judge [[Thomas F. McGuire]], worked with their supporters to secure the statute to establish the district. H.B. 23 authorized a 1969 vote in St. Louis City and County, where voters approved the creation of the tax district to fund the Zoo and Art Museum at a rate of 8 cents for every $100 assessed. The Science Center, which had previously received no tax benefit, was added at a rate of 4 cents for every $100 assessed.<ref name=mzdstl>{{cite web |url=http://www.mzdstl.org/History.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-12-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100125165028/http://www.mzdstl.org/History.htm |archivedate=2010-01-25 |df= }}</ref>
[[Earl Wipfler]] was selected as the first Executive Director of the district in 1972, and he guided the initial creation of the district's budgeting and accounting procedures. The [[Missouri Supreme Court]] approved them.<ref name=mzdstl/> Wipfler served as Executive Director until 1990.
The Missouri Botanical Garden was added as the district's fourth subdistrict in 1983, and the History Museum in 1988.<ref name=mzdstl/>
[[Olney F. Otto]] served as the district's second executive director from 1990 until his death in 2001. [[Mr. J. Patrick Dougherty]] has served in the position since.<ref name=mzdstl/>
==Revenue== From an initial annual revenue of $3.9 million in 1972, the district grew to $72 million in 2008. In the past few years, around 85% of these funds have come from the county with the city providing only about 15%. Though the tax is the same in both places, the disparity in income and population accounts for the difference in money generated.<ref name=index>{{cite web |url=http://www.mzdstl.org/index.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-12-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091207114623/http://www.mzdstl.org/index.htm |archivedate=2009-12-07 |df= }}</ref>
==Governing Board== The eight-member governing board is composed of four appointments from St. Louis City, chosen by the mayor, and four from St. Louis County, chosen by the county executive. The terms last four years, and two positions open up on January 1 each year, one for the city and one for the county.<ref name=mzdstl/>
==Criticism== {{POV-section|date=February 2015}} {{Unreferenced-section|date=November 2016}} Through the government subsidy, all five subdistricts are able to operate without charging admission. Some people have questioned whether tourists and residents of areas outside St. Louis City and St. Louis County should continue to be allowed free admission, and that it might be just to charge them, as they contribute nothing to the regional attractions. The exception to this is the Missouri Botanical Garden, which charges admission to non-residents of St. Louis City and County at double the rate of residents. Institutional and political efforts to persuade neighboring [[Jefferson County, Missouri|Jefferson]], [[St. Charles County, Missouri|St. Charles]] and other counties to pass tax levies to join the district (and contribute to operations of the regional attractions) have not been successful. The issue of equity has come up intermittently throughout the district's history.
==Emulation== The MZMD is one of the earliest, largest, and most successful cultural districts of its kind. Other cities have created similar programs and tax districts based on the St. Louis model.<ref name=index/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.mzdstl.org/index.htm District Website]
{{Coord|38.65028|-90.33568|format=dms|display=title|type:adm2nd_region:US-MO}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Metropolitan Zoological Park And Museum District}} [[Category:Geography of St. Louis]] [[Category:Museum districts]] [[Category:Missouri Botanical Garden]] [[Category:Park districts in the United States]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Feminism and the arts]]; added [[Category:Feminist art organizations]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
'''The Native American Women Playwrights Archive (NAWPA)''' is a collection of manuscripts and related items pertaining to Native American women in theater.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=afENAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA304&dq=Native+American+Women+Playwrights+Archive&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiwja2CmZ_bAhUOWqwKHfeHDZgQ6AEIMzAC#v=onepage&q=Native%20American%20Women%20Playwrights%20Archive&f=false|title=The Native American Renaissance: Literary Imagination and Achievement|last=Velie|first=Alan R.|last2=Lee|first2=A. Robert|date=2013-11-11|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|year=|isbn=9780806151311|location=|pages=304|language=en}}</ref> It was established in 1997 at [[Miami University]] in Oxford, Ohio and is located in the university's [[King Library (Miami University)|King Library]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2AUgAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA201&dq=Native+American+Women+Playwrights+Archive&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiwja2CmZ_bAhUOWqwKHfeHDZgQ6AEIPTAE#v=onepage&q=Native%20American%20Women%20Playwrights%20Archive&f=false|title=The Cambridge Companion to Native American Literature|last=Porter|first=Joy|last2=Roemer|first2=Kenneth M.|date=2005-07-21|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=|isbn=9781139827027|location=|pages=201|language=en}}</ref> The archive is a repository for [[Spiderwoman Theater]] and contains promotional and personal documents associated with the theater troupe and its members.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://spec.lib.miamioh.edu/home/nawpa/|title=Native American Women Playwrights Archive {{!}} Miami University Libraries Steward & Sustain Department|website=spec.lib.miamioh.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-15}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/741563442|title=Footpaths & bridges : voices from the Native American Women Playwrights Archive|last=|first=|date=2008|publisher=University of Michigan Press|others=Huston-Findley, Shirley., Howard, Rebecca|year=|isbn=0472034782|edition= 1st paperback |location=Ann Arbor|pages=|oclc=741563442}}</ref>
== History == NAWPA began in 1996 with Dr. William Wortman, humanities librarian, and John Allen Johnson, a Cherokee and African American graduate student researching Native American women playwrights at Miami University.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/865063187|title=The Native American renaissance : literary imagination and achievement|others=Velie, Alan R., 1937-, Lee, A. Robert, 1941-|isbn=9781461952046|location=Norman|oclc=865063187}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6dg0AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA58&dq=Native+American+Women+Playwrights+Archive&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiwja2CmZ_bAhUOWqwKHfeHDZgQ6AEIODAD#v=onepage&q=Native%20American%20Women%20Playwrights%20Archive&f=false|title=Indigenous North American Drama: A Multivocal History|last=Däwes|first=Birgit|date=2013|publisher=SUNY Press|year=|isbn=9781438446615|location=|pages=58|language=en}}</ref> Johnson had difficulty finding material to research, so the two built the archive by approaching writers and performers to add to the collection.<ref name=":1" />
== Holdings == The Native American Women Playwrights Archive in the King Library's Walter Havighurst Special Collections of Miami University contains play manuscripts and other materials including audio and video recordings of performances (VHS tapes, audio cassettes, CDs, and DVDs), photographs, newspaper articles, reviews, flyers, and posters.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> The archive also holds administrative and financial documents, notes, forms, mailings lists, and correspondence pertaining to the management of the archive and sponsored conferences and events.<ref name=":0" />
Other holdings include documents relating to the work of Spiderwoman Theater, such as photographs of performances, play programs, interviews, and personal accounts from the members of the theater troupe. There are also documents regarding the legal dispute with Marvel Comics over the name "Spiderwoman."<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
All the materials in NAWPA are open-access and available for anyone to read in the library. NAWPA continuously adds new playwrights and works to its collection. The archive encourages "playwrights at any level of development"<ref name=":0" /> to submit their materials.
== Publications == In 2008, University of Michigan Press published ''Footpaths and Bridges: Voices from the Native American Women Playwrights Archive'', edited by Shirley A. Huston-Findley and Rebecca Howard. The anthology includes a number of scripts from NAWPA and critical commentary on the recurring themes in the plays.<ref name=":1" /> Other related publications include:
* ''Performing Worlds into Being: Native American Women's Theater'', edited by Ann Elizabeth Armstrong, Kelli Lyon Johnson, and William A. Wortman (2009) * ''Repairing the Web: Spiderwoman's Children Staging the New Human Being'' by Jill L. Carter (2010) * ''Seventh Generation: An Anthology of Native American Plays'', edited by Mimi Gisofi D'Aponte (1999) * ''Staging Coyote's Dream: An Anthology of First Nations Drama in English V.1 & 2'', edited by Monique and Ric Knowles (2003)
== See also == * [[Spiderwoman Theater]] * [[:Category:Native American dramatists and playwrights|Native American dramatists and playwrights]] * [[:Category:Indigenous theatre|Indigenous theatre]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.spiderwomantheater.org/ Spiderwoman Theater official website]

{{Infobox company | name = Native Design Ltd. | logo =File:Native_Design_Limited_logo_and_registered_trademark.png | type = Independent | hq_location = [[London]] and [[San Francisco]] | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = Morten Warren, Founder and CEO Marcus Hoggarth, President and CCO [[James Hilton (designer)|James Hilton]] CCO Sarika Haggipavlou, CFO and COO | services = [[Strategy]]
[[User experience]]
Digital and Physical Product design
[[Interaction design]]
[[Service design]]
[[Industrial design]]
[[Engineering]]
Technology services
Business Transformation and Consulting
[[Product development]] | num_employees = 200 | foundation = {{start date|1997|09}} in [[London, England]] | homepage = {{url|native.com}} }} '''Native Design''' is a British design and innovation company {{cite web|last1=Dowdy|first1=Clare|title=Brand Britain|url=https://monocle.com/magazine/issues/49/brand-britain/|website=Monocle|accessdate=20 June 2017}} {{subscription required}} whose work has been used by companies and institutions such as [[Anheuser-Busch InBev|ABinBev]], [[Audi]], [[Bang & Olufsen]], [[Baxter International|Baxter]], [[BBC]], [[Bentley]], [[Bowers & Wilkins]], [[Canal+|Canal Plus]], [[Coloplast]], [[Diageo]], [[Ford Motor Company|Ford,]] [[Here (company)|Here]], [[Hewlett-Packard|HP]], [[Illumina (company)|Illumina]], [[Microsoft]], [[Nespresso]], [[Novo Nordisk]], [[Pernod Ricard]], [[SFR]], [[Skype Technologies|Skype]], Santander, and [[VEON|Veon]].{{cite web|last1=Baker|first1=Hannah|title=Native Design's Morten Warren|url=http://www.director.co.uk/morten-warren-native-design-headspace-21-april-2015/|website=Director|accessdate=25 July 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Oakes|first1=Omar|title=AKQA co-founder James Hilton resurfaces at design studio Native|url=http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/akqa-co-founder-james-hilton-resurfaces-design-studio-native/1418172|website=Campaign|accessdate=25 July 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Oster|first1=Erik|title=AKQA Co-Founder James Hilton Joins Design Studio Native as Co-CCO|url=http://www.adweek.com/agencyspy/akqa-co-founder-james-hilton-joins-design-studio-native-as-co-cco/122159|website=Adweek|accessdate=25 July 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Dawood|first1=Sarah|title=AKQA co-founder James Hilton moves to Native|url=https://www.designweek.co.uk/issues/5-11-december-2016/akqa-co-founder-james-hilton-moves-native/|website=Design Week|accessdate=25 July 2017}} Native works across the spectrum from automotive to consumer electronics, telecommunications and healthcare. The company is based in London and San Francisco and employs 200 staff. == History and Work == Native Design was founded in 1997 by former Manager of Design at [[Bowers & Wilkins]], [[Morten Villiers Warren]].{{cite web|title=Bowers & Wilkins|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bowers_%26_Wilkins|website=Wikipedia|accessdate=20 June 2017}} Morten designed the "Emphasis Speakers" on the cover of Art of Noise's "Below the Waste" album.{{cite web|title=Below the Waste|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Below_the_Waste|website=Wikipedia|accessdate=20 June 2017}} After the success of their early work, the company developed a long-standing relationship {{cite book|last1=Nobuyuki|first1=Fu|title=Speaker Book 2017|date=2017|publisher=ONGAKU SHUPPAN-SHA|pages=14}} and collaboration with Bowers & Wilkins, designing earphones {{cite web|last1=Dowdy|first1=Clare|title=Design space: A more ergonomic earphone|url=https://www.ft.com/content/41f2efc6-c8fb-11e0-aed8-00144feabdc0|website=Financial Times|accessdate=20 June 2017}}{{subscription required}} the Zeppelin iPod dock and loudspeaker {{cite web|last1=Ozler|first1=Levent|title=A Zeppelin in the Livingroom|url=https://www.dexigner.com/news/15623|website=Dexigner|accessdate=20 June 2017}} and the PM1 loudspeaker.{{cite web|title=Bowers & Wilkins PM1 - exclusive interview with designer Morten Warren|url=http://blog.bowers-wilkins.com/news/new-products/bowers-wilkins-pm1-exclusive-interview-with-designer-morten-warren/|website=Bowers & Wilkins Blog|accessdate=20 June 2017}} Morten is credited with being responsible for today's sleek, contemporary shape.https://www.mrporter.com/journal/journal_issue115/9 Working with the HP Design Team in 2014, Native created the [[Sprout (computer)|Sprout]], a touch screen computer with both vertical and horizontal screens, which "aims to help designers move between physical and digital platforms seamlessly".{{cite web|last1=Dawood|first1=Sarah|title=Hewlett Packard to launch dual-screen desktop computer|url=https://www.designweek.co.uk/hewlett-packard-to-launch-dual-screen-desktop-computer/|website=Design Week|accessdate=20 June 2017}} In 2015, HP's CEO [[Meg Whitman]] called for a unification across HP's GBUs and thus kick-started concept visioning with Native.http://www.danielhuang.com/Laserjet-Refresh Native was commissioned to create the new user experience and homepage for the BBC in 2015.{{cite web|last1=Baker|first1=Hannah|title=Morten Warren, Native Design|url=http://www.director.co.uk/morten-warren-native-design-headspace-21-april-2015/|website=Director|accessdate=20 June 2017}} Coloplast employed Native to create the "Design DNA" in 2016, which won a Gold Lion at the Cannes Lions Festival of Creativity.{{cite web|last1=Oakes|first1=Omar|title=Google's wearable clothes idea wins Cannes Grand Prix for Product Design|url=http://www.campaignlive.com/article/googles-wearable-clothes-idea-wins-cannes-grand-prix-product-design/1399817|website=Campaign|accessdate=20 June 2017}}{{cite web|title=Cannes Lions 2016 - Product Design Gold Lion for COLOPLAST DESIGN DNA|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MFjItWPmSaY|website=Youtube|accessdate=20 June 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Gwynn|first1=Simon|title=UK companies lead nominations in Product Design Lions|url=http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/uk-companies-lead-nominations-product-design-lions/1399262|website=Campaign|accessdate=20 June 2017}} {{subscription required}} The creation "has been so successful for Coloplast that it is now embedded in the culture of the company worldwide" and set a new standard for products that make independent living easier for people with intimate healthcare needs.{{cite web|last1=Cheves|first1=Olivia|title=SHOREDITCH STUDIO WINS INTERNATIONAL ACCLAIM FOR INSPIRING DESIGNS|url=http://madeinshoreditch.co.uk/2015/10/16/shoreditch-studio-wins-international-acclaim-inspiring-designs/|website=Made in Shoreditch|accessdate=29 June 2017}} Subsequently, Forbes named the company as one of the "Top 25 Most Innovative Companies of 2016".{{cite web|title=Top 25 Most Innovative Companies 2016|url=https://www.forbes.com/pictures/elem45igi/no-22-coloplast/#49bc59326dbe|website=Forbes|accessdate=20 June 2017}} Native was recently honoured with the International Design Excellence Gold Award{{Cite web|url=http://www.idsa.org/awards/idea/digital-interaction/definitive-autonomous-car-experience|title=The Definitive Autonomous Car Experience|last=IDSA|first=|date=24 September 2018|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} for its work with the [[Ford Motor Company]] on the creation of their future car experience known as the [[Self-driving car|Autonomous Vehicle]] Simulator (AVS). It was created in response to global research and identifies the digital & physical experiences that people want when they no longer need to drive. AVS is a demonstration platform that reimagines transportation choice and business models beyond the [[Sport utility vehicle|SUV]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.nbc-2.com/story/39159419/native-design-honored-with-international-design-excellence-gold-award|title=Native Design Honored With International Design Excellence Gold Award|last=|first=|date=24 September 2018|work=NBC 2|access-date=}} The work generated hundreds of new patents for Ford == Awards and recognition == The company was the first British design company to win both Gold and Best in Show at the IDSA International Design Excellence Awards (IDEA).{{cite web|title=Morten Warren, I/IDSA|url=http://www.idsa.org/members/morten-warren|website=IDSA|accessdate=28 June 2017}} * Gold at the [[Industrial Designers Society of America|IDSA]] [[International Design Excellence Awards]] for the Definitive Autonomous Car Experience for [[Ford Motor Company]] *Gold at the [[Industrial Designers Society of America|IDSA]] [[International Design Excellence Awards]] for the Zeppelin [[iPod]] dock and [[loudspeaker]] for [[Bowers & Wilkins]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.idsa.org/awards/idea/entertainment/zeppelin-ipod-speaker-dock|title=Zeppelin iPod Speaker Dock|date=2010-05-23|work=Industrial Designers Society of America - IDSA|access-date=2017-03-14|language=en}} * Gold and Best in Show at the [[Industrial Designers Society of America|IDSA]] [[International Design Excellence Awards]] for the Design DNA for healthcare company [[Coloplast]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.idsa.org/awards/idea/design-strategy/coloplast-design-dna|title=BEST IN SHOW - Coloplast Design DNA|date=2015-07-06|work=Industrial Designers Society of America - IDSA|access-date=2017-04-03|language=en}} * Gold at the [[Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity|Cannes Festival of Creativity]] for the Design DNA for [[Coloplast]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.canneslionsarchive.com/winners/entry/780751/coloplast-design-dna|title=Cannes Lions Winners :: Cannes Lions Archive|website=www.canneslionsarchive.com|access-date=2017-03-14}} * 5 [[Red Dot|Red Dot Awards]] for the [[Hewlett-Packard|HP]] PHI Design Language Strategy.{{Cite web|url=http://red-dot.de/pd/online-exhibition/?lang=en&c=0&a=0&y=2016&i=0&oes=Native+Design|title=online-exhibition {{!}} Red Dot Award: Product Design|website=red-dot.de|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-31}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * [http://www.native.com/ Official website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Native Design}} [[Category:Design companies established in 1997]] [[Category:Online companies]] [[Category:Product designers]] [[Category:Interface designers]] [[Category:Companies based in the London Borough of Hackney]] [[Category:British companies established in 1997]] [[Category:Design companies of the United Kingdom]]

revision.text:
{{Use American English|date=July 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} '''Naval Nuclear Propulsion Information (NNPI)''' is a category of [[intellectual capital]] defined by the [[United States Navy]] to be "classified or unclassified information concerning the design, arrangement, development, manufacture, testing, operation, administration, training, maintenance, and repair of the propulsion plants of naval nuclear-powered ships and prototypes, including the associated shipboard and shore-based nuclear support facilities.." <ref>{{cite web |url=http://doni.daps.dla.mil/Directives/09000%20General%20Ship%20Design%20and%20Support/09-200%20Propulsion%20Plants%20Support/N9210.3%20(Unclas%20Portion).pdf |title=OPNAVINST N9210.3, SAFEGUARDING OF NAVAL NUCLEAR PROPULSION INFORMATION (NNPI), 6/7/2010, Unclassified Portion, page 1-1, Definition|accessdate=February 2012}}</ref>
Not all NNPI is [[classified information]]. While most NNPI is sensitive, the Navy recognizes that the public has an interest in [[Natural environment|environmental]], [[safety]], and [[health]] information, and that the basic [[research]] carried out by the Navy can be useful to [[industry]]. Unclassified information is therefore marked with the acronym "U-NNPI", but is still restricted as [[wikt:NOFORN|NOFORN]].<ref>See OPNAVINST N9210.3, esp. Chapters 3 and 4.</ref>
NNPI is explicitly protected information and is not released to the general public without authority. Those who release even NNPI-U without authority may be administratively punished, and even [[criminal law|criminally]] in the case of NNPI-C.{{Citation needed|date=April 2007}} NNPI is restricted from disclosure under the Arms Export Control Act, [https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/22/2778 22 USC §§2778] and [https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/22/2794 2794(7)]; such information is listed in the [http://ecfr.gpoaccess.gov/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=ecfr;sid=d148ef6a9390b1e27fc09865c734666c;rgn=div5;view=text;node=22%3A1.0.1.13.60;idno=22;cc=ecfr US Munitions List, 22 CFR §121.1], Category VI, paragraph (g).
In some instances, small events that would normally be reported as "Events" or LOC (Loss of Control) to the [[Nuclear Regulatory Commission]] from other licensees can be classified as NNPI-C.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://azstarnet.com/news/national/dangerous-tennessee-radioactive-spill-kept-from-public-papers-sealed/article_70fed1e3-e100-5f8e-91b6-4535b39289d6.html |title=Dangerous Tennessee radioactive spill kept from public; papers sealed |author=Associated Press |publisher=Arizona Daily Star |date=2007-08-21 }}</ref> This designation differs for similar "events" that occur on a secret network, which are referred to as "spillage".
==References== {{more footnotes|date=May 2008}} <references/>
* OPNAVINST N9210.3, SAFEGUARDING OF NAVAL NUCLEAR PROPULSION INFORMATION (NNPI), 6/7/2010
[[Category:United States government secrecy]] [[Category:Classified documents]] [[Category:Intellectual property law]] [[Category:Nuclear propulsion]] [[Category:Nuclear ships of the United States Navy|*]] [[Category:United States national security policy]]
{{USN-stub}}
