revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Oakley, Inc. | logo = [[Image:Oakley logo.svg|center|120px]] | type = [[Subsidiary]] | industry = {{ubl|[[Sunglasses]]|[[Clothing]]|[[Sports equipment]]}} | foundation = {{start date and age|1975}} | image = File:Oakleyheadquarters.jpg | image_caption = Oakley headquarters in Foothill Ranch | founder = [[James Jannard|Jim Jannard]] | location_city = [[Foothill Ranch, Lake Forest, California|Foothill Ranch]], [[California]] | location_country = [[United States]] | key_people = [[James Jannard|Jim Jannard]]: Chairman<ref>{{cite web|url=http://investor.oakley.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=67365&p=irol-govManage |title=Oakley Profile |publisher=Investor.oakley.com |accessdate=April 19, 2012}}</ref> | parent = [[Luxottica]] | homepage = {{URL|http://www.oakley.com|www.oakley.com}} }}
'''Oakley, Inc.''', based in [[Lake Forest, California]], and a subsidiary of [[Italy|Italian]] company [[Luxottica]] based in [[Milan]], designs, develops and manufactures sports performance equipment and lifestyle pieces including sunglasses, sports visors, ski/snowboard goggles, watches, apparel, [[backpack]]s, shoes, optical frames, and other accessories. Most items are designed in house at their head office, but some countries hold exclusive designs relevant to their market. Oakley currently holds more than 600 patents for eyewear, materials, and performance gear.<ref>{{cite web|title=Oakley Company Profile|url=http://www.oakley.com/en/?nav=TN-Oakley|accessdate=July 31, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/946356/000089256907001415/a35754e8vk.htm|title=Oakley, Inc.|website=www.sec.gov|access-date=2017-05-26}}</ref>
==History== Oakley was started by [[James Jannard]] in 1975 out of his garage with an initial investment of $300. The name "Oakley" came from Jim's English Setter, "Oakley Anne." Jannard began by selling what he called 'The Oakley Grip' out of the back of his car at [[motocross]] events. His [[Motorcycle handlebar|motorcycle grips]] were unlike other grips available at the time. The material is still used to make the earsocks on Oakley glasses, and many of the nose pieces and now the bands of their watches. Oakley went on to produce number plates, gloves, grips, elbow guards, chin guards, and goggles for the BMX and motocross communities.<ref name="Caldwell2014">{{cite book|last=Caldwell|first=Michael|title=The Unknown Billionaires: The life stories of 50 self-made men and women|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6n3_AwAAQBAJ&pg=PT84|date=11 July 2014|publisher=eBookPartnership.com|isbn=978-0-9784620-8-6|pages=84–89}}</ref> After selling Oakely Inc. to Italian Eyeware company [[Luxottica|Luxottica Group]] in 2007, founder James Jannard went on to found [[Red Digital Cinema Camera Company|Red Digital Cinema]].
In 1980, Jannard released a pair of [[goggles]] called the O-Frame. With the 'Oakley' logo present on the strap, the brand garnered increasing recognition and prominence throughout the sports industry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oakley.com/innovation/history |title=Oakley History |publisher=Oakley.com |accessdate=April 19, 2012}}</ref> In 1983, Oakley began selling ski goggles.<ref name="Oakley Inc">{{cite web|url=http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/Oakley-Inc-Company-History.html| title=Oakley Inc.|accessdate=June 9, 2010}}</ref>
The first Oakley sunglasses; Factory Pilot Eyeshades, were sport-oriented, resembling goggles and were released in 1984. These were followed in 1985 by the Oakley Frogskin, a casual sunglass style that was made in Japan.<ref name="Caldwell2014"/>
The company went public in 1995, raising $230 million.<ref name="LA Times: A Trip to Planet Oakley">{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1997-03-16/magazine/tm-38675_1_oakley-sunglasses|title=LA Times: A Trip to Planet Oakley|publisher=LA Times|accessdate=November 4, 2012|first=Ed |last=Leibowitz}}</ref>
In early 1996, Oakley had a pricing dispute with Italian company [[Luxottica]], the world's largest eyewear manufacturers and retailers. Luxottica stopped carrying Oakley's products in their stores, including Sunglass Hut, and Oakley's stock market value declined 33%.<ref name="SIXTYMINUTES2012">{{cite news|title=Sticker shock: Why are glasses so expensive?|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-18560_162-57527151/sticker-shock-why-are-glasses-so-expensive/|newspaper=[[60 Minutes]]|publisher=[[CBS News]]|date=October 7, 2012|accessdate=October 19, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/oakley-inc-history/ |title=History of Oakley, Inc. – FundingUniverse |publisher=Fundinguniverse.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-13}}</ref>
In 2001, Oakley bought Iacon, Inc., operator of mall-based sunglasses stores Sunglass Designs, Sporting Eyes, and Occhiali da Sole.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/865482/Oakley-to-buy-Iacon---a-sunglasses-retail-chain.html?pg=all |title=Oakley to buy Iacon a sunglasses retail chain |publisher=Deseret News |date=2001-09-24 |accessdate=2013-08-13}}</ref>
Oakley signed a four-year agreement to manufacture eyewear designed by themselves and [[Fox Racing]] in September 2004.<ref>[http://www.pinterest.com/eyewearoutlet "Fox Racing Signs Sunglasses Deal With Oakley." ''Bicycle Retailer''. September 7, 2004] April, 2012</ref>
Starting in 2004, Jannard bought large quantities of Oakley stock: $2 million in 2004, $16 million in 2005, and $4.6 million in early 2006, bringing his personal stake in the company to 63%.<ref name=sa500>{{cite journal|title=Why the Oakley Buyout Was No Surprise |date=June 27, 2007 |journal=S&A Digest|first=Graham|last=Summers}}</ref>
In 2006, Oakley acquired the [[Oliver Peoples]] group, a manufacturer of high-end fashion branded eyewear (under the Oliver Peoples, Mosley Tribes, and [[Paul Smith (fashion designer)|Paul Smith]] brands) for $55.7m,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2006/02/09/339240/93733/en/Oakley-Acquires-Oliver-Peoples-a-Leading-Fashion-Eyewear-Brand.html |title=Oakley Acquires Oliver Peoples - a Leading Fashion Eyewear Brand NYSE:OO |publisher=Globenewswire.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-13}}</ref> and Optical Shop of Aspen, a luxury eyewear retailer with fourteen stores.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.opticianonline.net/Articles/2006/03/15/15434/Oakley+buys+US+luxury+chain+Optical+Shop+of+Aspen.htm |title=Oakley buys US luxury chain Optical Shop of Aspen |publisher=Optician Online |date=2006-03-15 |accessdate=2013-08-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140429215104/http://www.opticianonline.net/Articles/2006/03/15/15434/Oakley+buys+US+luxury+chain+Optical+Shop+of+Aspen.htm |archivedate=2014-04-29 |df= }}</ref>
On June 21, 2007, Luxottica announced a plan to purchase Oakley in a cash deal worth $2.1 billion, paying a 16% premium over the extant share price.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/2007/06/21/luxottica-oakley-update-markets-equity-cx_vr_0621markets21.html |title=Luxottica's Shade-less Deal With Oakley |publisher=Forbes |date= |accessdate=2013-08-13}}</ref> The deal was completed on November 15, 2007, making Oakley part of a portfolio that includes brands such as [[Ray-Ban]], [[Persol]], and Vogue.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.moodiereport.com/document.php?c_id=1132&doc_id=14387 |title=Luxottica acquires rival Oakley in US$2.1 billion deal; creates global eyewear superforce |publisher=TheMoodieReport.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112211926/http://www.moodiereport.com/document.php?c_id=1132&doc_id=14387 |archivedate=2013-11-12 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Schweikart">{{cite book|last1=Schweikart|first1=Larry |last2=Pierson Doti|first2=Lynne |title=American Entrepreneur: The Fascinating Stories of the People Who Defined Business in the United States|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mC-dVPOSFoAC&pg=PA15|year=2009|publisher=AMACOM Div American Mgmt Assn|isbn=978-0-8144-1412-5|pages=15–16}}</ref>
During the preparations for the [[2010 Copiapó mining accident#Rescue – Operación San Lorenzo|ultimately successful rescue]] of thirty-three miners trapped for ten weeks in a [[2010 Copiapó mining accident|Chilean mine]] in October 2010, a journalist covering the story contacted Oakley about donating sunglasses to the rescue effort, aware that the miners would need eye protection after having spent weeks in darkness. Oakley donated 35 pairs of its Radar sports glasses, fitted with specially selected tints.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/scitech/2010/10/13/sports-sunglasses-aim-ease-miners-transition/ |title=Sports Sunglasses Can Aid Chilean Miners' Transition |agency=Associated Press |publisher=Fox News Channel |date=October 13, 2010 |accessdate=October 14, 2010}}</ref> [[File:Oakley sunglasses.jpg|thumb|A pair of Oakley sunglasses]] Oakley sponsored members of the US Olympic Team in 2012.<ref name="oly">{{cite news|date=July 7, 2012|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-295506771.html|title=Oakley and Olympic Gold Medalist Kerri Walsh Reveal "BEYOND REASON" Installation|newspaper=Marketing Weekly News {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}}}</ref>
In August 2013, Oakley sold its REVO brand to Sequential Brands for $20m.<ref>{{cite web|author=Kari Hamanaka |url=http://www.ocbj.com/news/2013/aug/12/oakley-sells-revo-brand-20m/ |title=Oakley Sells REVO Brand for $20M | Orange County Business Journal |publisher=Ocbj.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-13}}</ref><ref name="aqu WWD 2013">{{cite web | url=http://www.wwd.com/business-news/mergers-acquisitions/sequential-buys-revo-brand-7075657?src=nl/mornReport/20130805 | title=Sequential Buys Revo Brand From Oakley Inc. | publisher=WWD | date=5 August 2013 | accessdate=5 August 2013 | author=Young, Vicki M.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Sequential Brands Group Announces Acquisition of the REVO Brand|url=http://ir.sequentialbrandsgroup.com/releasedetail.cfm?releaseid=782662|website=sequentialbrandsgroup.com|publisher=Sequential Brands Group|accessdate=28 May 2015}}</ref>
==Technical innovation==
Most of Oakley's technological designs, fashion pieces, gear, etc. were developed with extensive athlete input and testing in the field – including extreme conditions. Oakley also maintains US Standard Issue, which provides U.S. military and law enforcement eye protection. Oakley M Frame sunglasses are included as part of the U.S. Army's Authorized Protective Eyewear List (APEL), and have been assigned a NSN number for ordering through military supply channels.<ref>{{cite book|title=Transforming the defense industrial base a roadmap|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0t_GKF5rmsYC&pg=SL2-PA28|year=2003|publisher=DIANE Publishing|isbn=978-1-4289-8277-2|pages=27–30}}</ref> The company has also built at least one 'golf [[hovercraft]]', intended as an all terrain replacement for conventional [[golf cart]]s, in partnership with the professional golfer, [[Bubba Watson]]. {{clear}} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==External links== {{commonscat|Oakley, Inc.}} *{{official website|http://www.oakley.com/}} *{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/19961224132136/http://www.oakley.com/ |date=December 24, 1996 |title=Oakley, Inc. }}

revision.text:
{{BLP sources|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox person | image = | name = Olivier Zahm | image_size = 300px | caption = Zahm pictured in 2018 for ''Tecknikart Magazine '' | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1963|09|25}} | birth_place = [[Paris]], [[France]] | nationality = [[French people|French]] | residence = [[Paris]], [[France]] and [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] | education = Université Panthéon-Sorbonne | occupation = [[Magazine editor]], [[photographer]], [[art critic]], [[writer]], [[fashion journalist]] | known_for = Editor-in-chief and co-founder of Purple Magazine | years_active = 1985–present | children = 2 | website = {{url|purple.fr}} }} '''Olivier Zahm''' (born 25 September 1963) is a French [[Editing|magazine editor,]] [[art critic]], [[art director]], [[curator]], writer, and [[photographer]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/04/fashion/04ZAHM.html|title=Publisher in the Warhol Mold|last=Morgan|first=Spencer|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/2017/11/interview-olivier-zahm-on-the-purple-25th-anniversary.html|title=A French Fashion Editor on the Difference Between Paris, New York, and L.A.|last=Swanson|first=Carl|work=The Cut|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=http://purple.fr|title=purple DIARY|website=Purple|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-23}} He is the co-founder, owner, and current editor-in-chief of the bi-annual [[art]] and [[fashion]] magazine ''[[Purple]].''{{Cite news|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/m-gens-portrait/article/2015/10/09/olivier-zahm-dandy-a-louer_4786361_4497229.html|title=Olivier Zahm, dandy à louer|work=Le Monde.fr|access-date=2018-09-23|language=fr-FR}}[https://www.businessoffashion.com/community/people/olivier-zahm] In addition to his innovative print publishing, he is a recognized pioneering cultural influence at the dawn of the electronic era during ''the [[Digital Revolution]]''[[Digital Revolution|.]] His early blogs{{Cite web|url=http://purple.fr/|title=purple DIARY|website=Purple|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-23}} garnered notoriety, and featured highly stylized photographs taken by him, that took his audience on daily tours of his fantasyland populated by the artists, intellectuals, designers, filmmakers, socialites, models and celebrities who regularly appeared in his magazine{{Cite news|url=https://www.interviewmagazine.com/culture/olivier-zahm-purple-diary|title=The Man and the Brand: Olivier Zahm - Interview Magazine|date=2010-03-10|work=Interview Magazine|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://purple.fr/night/|title=purple NIGHT|work=Purple|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://i-d.vice.com/en_au/article/9kby7d/purple-reign-tbt-to-2010-when-i-d-met-olivier-zahm|title=purple reign: #tbt to 2010, when i-D met olivier zahm|date=2017-05-04|work=I-d|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en-au}}. His [[Aesthetics|aesthetic]] has been described as anti-fashion, [[counterculture]], and unfettered by the constraints of the mainstream publishing world{{Cite web|url=https://www.semipermanent.com/profiles/olivier-zahm|title=Olivier Zahm {{!}} Semi Permanent|website=Semi Permanent|language=en|access-date=2018-09-23}}. His online activity served as an early electronic precursor to popular social media platforms like Facebook and Instagram. His magazine remains one of the only independent and privately owned publications of its kind{{Cite news|url=http://www.papermag.com/olivier-zahm-le-provocateur-1427384256.html|title=Olivier Zahm: Le Provocateur|date=2014-09-07|work=PAPER|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}}. Created in the beginning of the ''1990s'' - it still remains a major reference for other alternative magazines today{{Cite news|url=http://www.bystylingamsterdam.com/2012/03/05/purples-editor-in-chief-olivier-zahm-accuses-muse-magazine-of-shameless-copying/|title=Purple’s Editor-In-Chief Olivier Zahm accuses Muse Magazine of Shameless Copying!|date=2012-03-05|work=by Styling Amsterdam|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/2012/02/olivier-zahm-accuses-purple.html|title=Olivier Zahm Accuses Muse Magazine of Copying Purple|work=The Cut|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en}}. == Early life and education == [[File:Olivier Zahm in 1979.jpg|thumb|333x333px|Zahm pictured in [[1979]] in [[Paris]]]] Olivier Zahm was born and raised in [[Paris]], France.{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessoffashion.com/community/people/olivier-zahm|title=Olivier Zahmis One of the 500 People Shaping the Global Fashion Industry|work=The Business of Fashion|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-GB}} He was the eldest of three children born to two university professors. His parents, who were both students at the time of his birth, raised Zahm and his other siblings in student quarters that were designed by [[Charlotte Perriand]] and [[Jean Prouvé]], located at [[:fr:Résidence_universitaire_Jean-Zay|Résidence Universitaire Jean-Zay]] in [[Antony, Hauts-de-Seine|Antony]].{{Cite news|url=https://i-d.vice.com/en_us/article/9kby7d/purple-reign-tbt-to-2010-when-i-d-met-olivier-zahm|title=purple reign: #tbt to 2010, when i-D met olivier zahm|date=2017-05-04|work=I-d|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en-us}}  Much of his early childhood was spent in academic settings, particularly- during the volatile period of civil unrest in France that broke out in [[May 1968]]''.''{{Cite news|url=https://i-d.vice.com/en_us/article/9kby7d/purple-reign-tbt-to-2010-when-i-d-met-olivier-zahm|title=purple reign: #tbt to 2010, when i-D met olivier zahm|date=2017-05-04|work=I-d|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en-us}}  The protests reached such a point that political leaders feared civil war or revolution. The unrest began with a series of student occupation protests against [[capitalism]], [[consumerism]], [[American imperialism]], and traditional institutions, values and order. Many of the new and radical ideas surrounding Zahm, immersing his youth in tumultuous generational discord, stayed with him, shaping his views on art, philosophical ideas and lifestyle choices.  He leveraged his profound formative experience using it as a tool to build aspects and themes that remain prevalent in his personal and professional life in adulthood.  He told The [[The New York Times|New York Times]] in 2010 that he, “remembers summers spent vacationing in the South of France with his parents in a community of like minded free spirits”{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/04/fashion/04ZAHM.html|title=Publisher in the Warhol Mold|last=Morgan|first=Spencer|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}} - who he labeled hippies. It was the ''1970s'', the decade of sex revolution and Zahm's parents were committed to [[free love]]'','' [[Naturism|nudism]] and [[Polyamory|polyamourous]] relationships. "My parents had a lot of lovers, they had a lot of affairs. At the time, my parents were really part of this alternative movement in Paris but quite bourgeois too. It wasn't San Francisco or New York. It was the French way{{Cite news|url=https://i-d.vice.com/en_au/article/9kby7d/purple-reign-tbt-to-2010-when-i-d-met-olivier-zahm|title=purple reign: #tbt to 2010, when i-D met olivier zahm|date=2017-05-04|work=I-d|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en-au}}." Zahm’s love of magazines began when he was a teenager in the Paris suburbs. “We used to steal porn magazines in the bookstores and shops and look at them during school,” he says. “It was fun and secret. This is where my obsession for magazines comes from. Magazines used to reveal and give us access to sex, fashion, music and art. TV never did that, and books are mostly academic. Magazines were a symbol of freedom.” {{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/2013/02/olivier-zahm-fashions-most-libidinal-editor.html|title=Riding Around Paris With Olivier Zahm, Fashion’s Most Libidinal Editor|work=The Cut|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en}} He studied [[Philosophy|philosophy,]] [[history]], [[semiotics]] and [[literature]] at the [[Sorbonne University|Sorbonne]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.parismatch.com/Culture/Livres/Olivier-Zahm-l-anar-chic-purple-Fashion-156808|title=Olivier Zahm, l’anar chic|last=Match|first=Paris|access-date=2018-09-24|language=fr-FR}}. His father, Claude, taught philosophy, and Zahm was on track to do the same, before realizing, at 25, that he preferred life outside “la tour d’ ivoire.” {{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/2013/02/olivier-zahm-fashions-most-libidinal-editor.html|title=Riding Around Paris With Olivier Zahm, Fashion’s Most Libidinal Editor|work=The Cut|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en}} Zahm's youngest sister committed suicide in 1994 at the age of 20. {{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/2013/02/olivier-zahm-fashions-most-libidinal-editor.html|title=Riding Around Paris With Olivier Zahm, Fashion’s Most Libidinal Editor|work=The Cut|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en}} == Career == Before entering the world of fashion, Zahm worked as an art critic with widespread recognition for his work as a curator as well as his participation in over 150 exhibitions featuring international contemporary art. {{Cite web|url=https://magpile.com/purple-prose/2/|title=Purple Prose , #2|website=Magpile|access-date=2018-09-24}}In responding to the superficial glamour of the 1980s, Zahm co-founded Purple Prose magazine{{Cite web|url=https://magpile.com/purple-prose/about/|title=Purple Prose magazine on Magpile|website=magpile.com|access-date=2018-09-23}}. In the introduction of Purple Anthology, Zahm shares why he chose to create Purple Prose:{{Cite news|url=https://www.rizzoliusa.com/book/9780847830206/|title=Purple Anthology: Art Prose Fashion Music Architecture Sex - Rizzoli New York|work=Rizzoli New York|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://purple.fr/magazine/fw-2008-issue-10/purple-anthology/|title=Purple Anthology - purple MAGAZINE|work=Purple|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en-US}}
''"We launched Purple Prose in the early 1990s without any means, and without any experience, because we wanted to make a magazine that was radically different. We wanted to support the artists around us that no one else supported, much less talked about. It would be a form of opposition of our own".'' {{Cite book|title=Purple Anthology|last=Zahm|first=Olivier|last2=Fleiss|first2=Elein|publisher=Rizzoli|year=2008|isbn=978-0-8478-3020-6|location=New York City|pages=introduction}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/Purple-Anthology-Prose-Fashion-Architecture/dp/0847830209|title=Purple Anthology: Art Prose Fashion Music Architecture Sex|date=2008-05-27|publisher=Rizzoli|isbn=9780847830206|editor-last=Zahm|editor-first=Olivier|location=New York|language=English|editor-last2=Fleiss|editor-first2=Elein}}
=== Art critic and curator (1985–1994) === During the beginning of the 80’s Zahm started to observe and take an interest in the art world. He liked the notion of “being everywhere and on the move”, following art fairs, meeting artists, educating himself in the universe of contemporary art while immersing himself into its social landscape.  Zahm’s gift of being a charismatic intellectual and having an eye for contemporary art made itself apparent early on. He found himself penning for the three leading art titles at the time [[Artforum|Art Forum]], Art Flash, [[Texte zur Kunst|Texte Zur Kunst]] and [[Art press|Art Presse]] and introduced a then unknown [[Jeff Koons]], [[Martin Kippenberger]], and [[Larry Clark]] to the European art world.   He started traveling to the United States and Japan, realizing he could set up his own operation and work agenda, 24/7. He told [[I-D|I-D magazine]] in 2010: [[File:Jan Van Osst, Sans titre, 1993.jpg|thumb|Jan Van Osst, Sans Titre, 1993 at L'Hiver De L'amour in [[Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris|Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville Paris]] curated by Zahm]]
"Freedom for me came from the art world because it was a place where I could meet the artists. I wanted to be a social critic. I was more interested in the category of intellectual, involving art and politics and writing sometimes. But I didn't want to be a writer necessarily, I just wanted to be part of an intellectual world." {{Cite news|url=https://i-d.vice.com/en_au/article/9kby7d/purple-reign-tbt-to-2010-when-i-d-met-olivier-zahm|title=purple reign: #tbt to 2010, when i-D met olivier zahm|date=2017-05-04|work=I-d|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en-au}} 
In 1989, while working at [[Artforum]],  Elien Fleiss, then a young gallery curator received a phone call from Zahm. She was looking for an art critic to write a manifesto against a journalist from a daily newspaper who she felt was writing insanities about contemporary art in general. Zahm agreed to do it, and that was the beginning of the encounter, which then became a love story. Their romance was short-lived, but their professional relationship was fruitful.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/04/fashion/04ZAHM.html|title=Publisher in the Warhol Mold|last=Morgan|first=Spencer|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en}}  In 1994, they curated “The Winter of Love,”https://www.moma.org/calendar/exhibitions/4589 a hit show for the [[Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris|Museum of Modern Art in Paris]] that they later took to [[MoMA PS1|P.S. 1]] in [[New York City|New York]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.moma.org/calendar/exhibitions/4589|title=The Winter of Love (L'Hiver de l'Amour) {{!}} MoMA|website=www.moma.org|language=en|access-date=2018-09-23}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.pressreader.com/france/art-press/20170521/282626032622730|title=PressReader.com - Connecting People Through News|website=www.pressreader.com|access-date=2018-09-23}} In May of  2017, Zahm published a book in collaboration with Donation Grau titled,' Une avant-garde sans avant-garde'.{{Cite web|url=http://www.lespressesdureel.com/ouvrage.php?id=3523|title=Olivier Zahm: Une avant-garde sans avant-garde – Les presses du réel (livre)|website=www.lespressesdureel.com|access-date=2018-09-24}}{{Cite news|url=https://i-d.vice.com/fr/article/3kbd8v/sans-dieu-ni-maitres-petite-lecon-davant-gardisme-par-olivier-zahm|title=sans dieu ni maitre, petite leçon d'avant-gardisme par olivier zahm|date=2017-04-25|work=I-d|access-date=2018-09-24|language=fr}}The book is a collection of Zahm’s most significant texts written during the last 30 years. It is above all a radical reading of art from the 1990s to the present. The [[anthology]] tries to decipher this chaotic, contradictory, oppressive, and ultra-creative period. The introductions that precede each chapter contextualize the selected texts, and develop the idea that the 1990s invented an avant-garde without an avant-garde, the issues of which are increasing and intensifying.{{Cite web|url=http://www.lespressesdureel.com/ouvrage.php?id=3523|title=Olivier Zahm: Une avant-garde sans avant-garde – Les presses du réel (livre)|website=www.lespressesdureel.com|access-date=2018-09-24}} {{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.fr/Une-avant-garde-sans-Olivier-Zahm/dp/2840665441|title=Une avant-garde sans avant-garde|last=recherche|first=résultats de|last2=Grau|first2=Donatien|date=2017-03-01|publisher=Les Presses du réel|isbn=9782840665441|location=Dijon; Zurich}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.jrp-ringier.com/pages/index.php?id_r=4&id_t=&id_p=18&id_b=2748|title=Olivier Zahm - Une avant-garde sans avant-garde|website=jrp-ringier|access-date=2018-09-24}}{{Cite web|url=https://livre.fnac.com/a10494503/Olivier-Zahm-Une-avant-garde-sans-avant-garde|title=Une avant-garde sans avant-garde Essai sur l'art - broché - Olivier Zahm - Achat Livre {{!}} fnac|website=livre.fnac.com|language=fr-FR|access-date=2018-09-26}}{{Cite news|url=http://purple.fr/diary/olivier-zahms-new-book-une-avant-garde-sans-avant-garde-co-edited-with-donatien-grau-is-available-now-to-pre-order/|title=Olivier Zahm's new book "Une avant-garde sans avant-garde" co-edited with Donatien Grau is available now to pre-order! - purple DIARY|date=2017-02-23|work=Purple|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}} === Purple === ==== Early day's of ''Purple'' (1992–2004) ==== Zahm gravitated towards the idea of working with magazines from the conception of his career in art. In 1992 Zahm and his partner Elien Fleiss printed the first issue of Purple Prose, a Parisian literary art zine.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ravelinmagazine.com/posts/les-chroniques-purple/|title=Les Chroniques Purple - Ravelin Magazine|date=2014-08-13|work=Ravelin Magazine|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.ebay.com/itm/PURPLE-PROSE-MAGAZINE-ISSUE-1-1992-OLIVIER-ZAHM-ELEIN-FLEISS-RARE-/121033472335|title=PURPLE PROSE MAGAZINE ISSUE #1 1992 OLIVIER ZAHM, ELEIN FLEISS *RARE* {{!}} eBay|website=eBay|language=en|access-date=2018-09-24}} Their goal was to create a new kind of space for artists to present their work and express their ideas; and to design a network through which people working in different disciplines, could easily access new information and each other and contributing to the early 90s alternative indie culture.{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/the-colour-purple-1249204.html|title=The colour purple|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-GB}} {{Cite news|url=https://www.businessoffashion.com/articles/creative-class/olivier-zahms-cocktail-of-intellect-sex-and-the-seventies|title=Olivier Zahm’s Cocktail of Intellect, Sex and the Seventies|date=2015-05-27|work=The Business of Fashion|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-GB}} Zahm liked the idea of a color sharing the title with an art magazine. [[Dike Blair]] an American artist suggested the title Purple Prose in reference to the literary term in which a prose text is so extravagent, ornate, or flowery that it breaks the flow and draws excessive attention to itself.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/2017/11/interview-olivier-zahm-on-the-purple-25th-anniversary.html|title=A French Fashion Editor on the Difference Between Paris, New York, and L.A.|last=Swanson|first=Carl|work=The Cut|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}}  Soon after the birth of Purple Prose, Zahm created spin-off publications like Purple Sexe, Purple Fiction and Purple Fashion. Zahm aimed at fusing together his two worlds, fashion and art, in creating Purple Fashion.{{Cite web|url=https://magpile.com/purple-prose/1/|title=Purple Prose , #1|website=Magpile|access-date=2018-09-24}}  A typical issue featured interviews, articles and presentations covering a wide range of topics and disciplines which include; film and video, politics, fashion, architecture, sexuality, science, photography and music. Each issue was built around a loose theme which serves to create a link between subjects-past examples have been: Indian Summer, Violet Violence, Post-Sex. With its international correspondents and cutting-edge design, Purple Prose had the distinctive feel of a truly global art zine. The texts were written in roughly equal parts French and English, without translations.{{Cite web|url=http://adaweb.walkerart.org/purple/info.html|title=Purple Prose|website=adaweb.walkerart.org|access-date=2018-09-24}} For many years the magazine was associated with a realist esthetic, that of the new photography of the early 1990s- of photographers like [[Juergen Teller]], [[Terry Richardson]], [[Wolfgang Tillmans]], and [[Mario Sorrenti]].  From a visual standpoint, the magazine represented a break from 80s imagery (like [[Richard Avedon]]’s photography for [[Versace]], for example.){{Cite news|url=https://tmagazine.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/05/30/fine-print-the-purple-anthology/?mtrref=www.google.com&gwh=2D16E914473B5E10578FBC9B4FEF8E2C&gwt=pay|title=Fine Print {{!}} 'The Purple Anthology'|last=Hruska|first=Jordan|work=T Magazine|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}} From an artistic standpoint, the artists from the early 1990s were raising up against art as a capitalist fetish; they were aligning themselves with the artistic social and political practices of the 1970s-- those of performance, [[video art]], [[Fluxus]], and the conceptual and minimalist [[avant-garde]]. The magazine was an integral part of this burgeoning context, which included the deconstruction of fashion by [[Martin Margiela]]{{Cite news|url=http://purple.fr/magazine/ss-2007-issue-7/retrospective-maison-martin-margiela/|title=Retrospective Maison Martin Margiela - purple MAGAZINE|work=Purple|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}} and [[Comme des Garçons|Comme des Garçsons]]{{Cite news|url=http://purple.fr/magazine/fw-2012-issue-18/rei-kawakubo/|title=Rei Kawakubo - purple MAGAZINE|work=Purple|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}}; the return of subtle political art, with that of [[Félix González-Torres|Felix Gonzalez- Torres]], [[Maurizio Cattelan]], and [[Philippe Parreno]], among others; photography of [[Juergen Teller]]; and [[Harmony Korine]] and [[Larry Clark]]’s independent filmmaking.{{Cite news|url=http://purple.fr/magazine/ss-2013-issue-19/harmony-korine/|title=Harmony Korine - purple MAGAZINE|work=Purple|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://purple.fr/magazine/ss-2013-issue-19/larry-clark/|title=Larry Clark - purple MAGAZINE|work=Purple|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}} ==== ''Purple Magazine'' (2017–present) ==== For its 25th anniversary issue{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/2017/11/interview-olivier-zahm-on-the-purple-25th-anniversary.html|title=A French Fashion Editor on the Difference Between Paris, New York, and L.A.|last=Swanson|first=Carl|work=The Cut|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}}, Purple celebrated the artists and models who incarnated the spirit of the magazine through their style, attitude, and personality: [[Cindy Sherman]], [[Wolfgang Tillmans]], [[Chloë Sevigny|Chloe Savigny]], [[Richard Prince]], [[Paul McCarthy]], [[Susan Cianciolo]] , [[Maurizio Cattelan|Maurizio Cattelan,]] and more.{{Cite news|url=https://www.standardhotels.com/culture/photos-purple-magazine-top-of-the-standard-september-2017|title=PHOTOS: Purple Magazine's 25th Anniversary Party at Top of The Standard|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://purple.fr/magazine/purple-25yrs-anniversary-issue/purple-25-years-25-covers/|title=Purple 25 Years 25 covers - purple MAGAZINE|work=Purple|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}} {{Cite news|url=https://www.vogue.com/article/purple-magazine-anniversary-ralph-lauren-paris-fashion-week|title=Purple Magazine Celebrates Its 25th Anniversary With Ralph Lauren in Paris|work=Vogue|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}}It was the first time the magazine printed multiple covers for one issue. 25 different covers showed  25 Purple icons.{{Cite news|url=http://purple.fr/diary/purple-25th-anniversary-issue-is-out-now/|title=PURPLE 25TH ANNIVERSARY ISSUE IS OUT NOW! - purple DIARY|date=2017-09-05|work=Purple|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.zadig-et-voltaire.com/eu/fr/zadig-backstage/zadig-backstage-society/zadigtribu-purple-25-zadigetvoltaire/|title=Purple 25th anniversary party with Zadig & Voltaire, New York|website=Zadig&Voltaire|language=fr|access-date=2018-09-24}} It was also the first time purple distributed hard-cover magazines instead of the traditional soft-cover print.{{Cite news|url=https://wwd.com/eye/parties/purple-magazine-25th-anniversary-olivier-zahm-chloe-sevigny-grace-hartzel-caroline-vreeland-11006313/|title=Purple Magazine Celebrates 25th Anniversary, Founder’s Birthday|last=Templeton|first=Lily|date=2017-09-26|work=WWD|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}} {{Cite news|url=https://wwd.com/eye/people/purple-reign-10970276/|title=Purple Reign|last=Foreman|first=Katya|date=2017-09-05|work=WWD|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}}He described in the editions Edito:
“It’s been years now that younger generations don’t use magazines to express themselves — at least not the way we did back in 1992. Social media now generally satisfy the need for images, contacts, and creativity. Publishing a magazine has become so expensive… An actual print object like Purple is a luxury item, which is why new alternative magazines don’t last more than a few years, are often bought, or simply disappear. Doing a luxury magazine today is one of the paradoxes of the Instagram era, when such things cost nothing… A magazine is not an ego trip… It’s a collective work by a group of creative people who believe in the artistic value of the print media and share a similar vision. (Thanks to all of them!) Every image, every single text, the choice of paper, the layout, even the choice of typefaces matters. Everything matters… Purple is made to last. Purple is made to capture a moment every season… In this period of global Internet obsession and digital amnesia, I think that means something{{Cite news|url=http://purple.fr/diary/purple-25th-anniversary-issue-is-out-now/|title=PURPLE 25TH ANNIVERSARY ISSUE IS OUT NOW! - purple DIARY|date=2017-09-05|work=Purple|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}}"
In 2017 Purple moved their US based headquarters and offices from [[New York City]] to [[Los Angeles]]. {{Cite news|url=https://wwd.com/business-news/media/purples-l-a-times-1202780271/|title=Purple’s L.A. Times|last=Foreman|first=Katya|date=2018-08-30|work=WWD|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://milk.xyz/articles/1955-milk-los-angeles-the-purple-magazine-party/|title=Milk Los Angeles – The Purple Magazine Party {{!}} Milk|last=Jon|date=2013-03-28|work=Milk|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}} === Freelance editor === In the year 2000, [[Serge July]], the founder and editor-in-chief of French national newspaper [[Libération]] hired Olivier Zahm to launch Liberation Style{{Cite web|url=http://www.ideanow.online/liberation.html|title=Liberation Style|website=www.ideanow.online|language=en|access-date=2018-09-24}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.parismatch.com/Culture/Livres/Olivier-Zahm-l-anar-chic-purple-Fashion-156808|title=Olivier Zahm, l’anar chic|last=Match|first=Paris|access-date=2018-09-24|language=fr-FR}}, an occasional Saturday supplement to the main paper. 15 issues were published every season until 2005. *Issue 1: Le Retour Paris *Issue 2: Personnalité Multiple *Issue 3: Plein Soleil *Issue 4: L’empire des Signes *Issue 5: Glamour *Issue 6: Special Creation *Issue 7: L’autre Amérique *Issue 8: La nuit *Issue 9: Femmes *Issue 10: Tokyo *Issue 11: Milan *Issue 12: Les Années Fatales *Issue 13: Best of L’ete 2005 *Issue 14: Special Hommes *Issue 15: Mystere Karl {{Cite web|url=https://www.liberation.fr/auteur/9971-olivier-zahm|title=Olivier ZAHM|website=Libération.fr|language=fr|access-date=2018-09-24}}{{Cite news|url=https://strip-project.com/archive/9-magazine/the-sisterhood-photography-anette-aurell-i-d-magazine-december-2001-january-2002/687|title=THE SISTERHOOD {{!}} PHOTOGRAPHY ANETTE AURELL {{!}} i-D MAGAZINE {{!}} DECEMBER 2001/JANUARY 2002|last=annaka|date=2016-05-11|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-gb}} In 2009 [[Chanel]] launched its very first magazine: 31 Rue Cambon. Chanel’s goal was to combine sales and information. [[Karl Lagerfeld]] delegated the artistic direction of the magazine which was not available to the public, but instead only the private cliental of Chanel to Zahm {{Cite web|url=https://www.tendances-de-mode.com/2009/11/17/1549-31-rue-cambon-le-magazine-chanel|title=31 Rue Cambon : le magazine Chanel - Tendances de Mode|website=www.tendances-de-mode.com|language=fr|access-date=2018-09-24}}{{Cite news|url=http://purple.fr/diary/the-new-chanel-magazine-31-rue-cambon-issue-3/|title=THE NEW CHANEL MAGAZINE, 31 RUE CAMBON, issue #3 - purple DIARY|date=2011-02-05|work=Purple|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.elle.com/fashion/news/a5892/olivier-zahm-made-a-corporate-mag-for-chanel-16120/|title=Olivier Zahm Made A 'Corporate Mag' for Chanel|date=2011-02-23|work=ELLE|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}} In 2018 Zahm designed a fanzine for [[Gucci]]’s FW2019 collection presented at [[Le Palace]] in Paris. The magazine was the 14th issue of Le Palace Magazine. {{Cite web|url=https://www.gucci.com/us/en/st/stories/inspirations-and-codes/article/spring-summer-2019-le-palace-magazine-fanzine|title=A new issue of Le Palace’s fanzine celebrating Gucci Spring Summer 2019 show by Alessandro Michele, with Purple’s Olivier Zahm and photos by Martin Parr.|website=www.gucci.com|language=en|access-date=2018-10-29}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.vogue.com/article/french-press-gucci-releases-new-issue-of-cult-fanzine-le-palace|title=Gucci Caps Off Its Paris Takeover by Releasing a New Issue of the Cult Fanzine, Le Palace|work=Vogue|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en}} == Photography == Zahm credited Lagerfeld for reigniting his sentiment for taking photos in 2005.  Zahm told WWD in an interview dedicated to Purple’s 25th Anniversary{{Cite news|url=https://wwd.com/eye/people/purple-reign-10970276/|title=Purple Reign|last=Foreman|first=Katya|date=2017-09-05|work=WWD|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}}:
“He (Lagerfeld) was buying these little digital cameras at the time, Sony Cyber-shots, a little pocket-size, flat, digital camera. He had a pile of them on his table and said: “Take this, if you’ll use it.” We had this long discussion about photography and I said, “Karl how can you want to be a photographer when you were friends with [[Helmut Newton]] because, me, I have [[Juergen Teller]] in my generation and I haven’t been able to do photography since I’ve known him, because he’s the best.” And he said: “Olivier, shut up. You don’t understand, photography is not about getting the right picture, it’s about documenting your everyday life. Remember [[Andy Warhol|Warhol]], do you think he was a good photographer? He always had a camera on him. Do like Warhol, do like me: Don’t let a day go by without taking a picture.”{{Cite news|url=https://wwd.com/eye/people/purple-reign-10970276/|title=Purple Reign|last=Foreman|first=Katya|date=2017-09-05|work=WWD|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}}
In 2009, he began documenting his late-night partying escapades in high-contrast black-and-white photographs which appeared on Purple Diary{{Cite news|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/09/09/fashion-s-naughtiest-photographer-olivier-zahm|title=Fashion’s Naughtiest Photographer, Olivier Zahm|last=Jones|first=Justin|date=2014-09-09|work=The Daily Beast|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}}, a notorious photo blog that would become the seed for a full Purple website. He has had shows of his photographic work at Half Gallery in New York, Colette in Paris , Leadapron in Los Angeles and The Last Gallery in Tokyo. {{Cite news|url=https://www.refinery29.com/olivier-zahm-s-secrets-of-photographing-women-exhibition-opens-tomorrow-at-leadapron-gallery|title=Purple's Olivier Zahm Launches A Photo Exhibit In L.A.|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://hypebeast.com/2010/3/olivier-zahm-purple-diary-exhibition-colette|title=Olivier Zahm "Purple Diary" Exhibition @ colette|work=HYPEBEAST|access-date=2018-09-24}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.jsbg.me/2011/05/26/%E2%80%9Cthe-secrets-of-photographing-women%E2%80%9D-lexpo-olivier-zahm/|title=“The Secrets of Photographing Women”, l’expo Olivier Zahm|work=JSBG.me|access-date=2018-09-24|language=fr-FR}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.semipermanent.com/profiles/olivier-zahm|title=Olivier Zahm {{!}} Semi Permanent|website=Semi Permanent|language=en|access-date=2018-09-24}} In addition to documenting his personal life on social media platform he continues to shoot many editorials and campaigns for various brands including [[Yves Saint Laurent (brand)|Yves Saint Laurent]], [[Chanel]], [[Giorgio Armani]], [[Uniqlo]],  [[Agent Provocateur (lingerie)|Agent Provocateur]], and magazines including [[Lui]], Vogue Russia, and Kadewe among others. {{Cite web|url=https://www.portraitsofgirls.com/photographer/olivier-zahm/|title=Olivier Zahm Archives — Portraits Of Girls|website=Portraits Of Girls|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-24}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/lifestyle/2017/03/03/30001-20170303ARTFIG00275-olivier-zahm-l-art-du-present.php|title=Olivier Zahm, l'art du présent|date=2017-03-03|work=FIGARO|access-date=2018-09-24|language=fr-FR}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.luimagazine.fr/sexy/fille-sexy/hedy-olivier-zham-morena/|title=Hedy vue par… Olivier Zahm|date=2015-09-21|work=LUI|access-date=2018-09-24|language=fr-FR}}{{Cite news|url=https://models.com/people/olivier-zahm|title=Olivier Zahm - Photographer|work=MODELS.com|access-date=2018-09-24}} In 2014, Zahm partnered with [[Rizzoli Bookstore|Rizzoli]] published O.Z. Diary, a cosmopolitan 500-page photo diary exposing the lifestyles of the creative elite through a series of intimate, autobiographical photographs. [[Glenn O'Brien]] contributed various texts for the book.{{Cite news|url=https://www.rizzoliusa.com/book/9780847841387/|title=O.Z.: Olivier Zahm: Diary - Rizzoli New York|work=Rizzoli New York|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}}{{Citation|last=Marc Jacobs|title=O.Z.: Olivier Zahm: Diary|date=2014-10-17|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2D_pyF4urBo|access-date=2018-09-26}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.onetshirt.eu/blogs/onetlikes/15770249-oz-diary-a-photographic-diary-of-fashion-art-and-sex-by-olivier-zahm|title=OZ Diary. A photographic diary of Fashion, Art and Sex by Olivier Zahm – ONETSHIRT|website=www.onetshirt.eu|language=en|access-date=2018-09-26}} == Personal life == Zahm has a son, Balthus, with designer Natacha Ramsay-Levi{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/fashion/people/natacha-ramsay-levi-meet-paris-it-girl-has-just-named-creative/|title=Who is Natacha Ramsay-Levi? Meet the Paris It-girl who has just been named creative director at Chloé|last=Leaper|first=Caroline|date=2017-03-10|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/27/fashion/chloe-natacha-ramsay-levi-paris-fashion-week.html|title=The New Chloé Girl|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/2010/07/olivier_zahms_girlfriend_dumpe.html|title=Olivier Zahm’s Girlfriend Dumped Him and He Blogged About It|work=The Cut|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}}, and a daughter, Asia, with writer Anna Dubosc. He currently is in a relationship with creative director and former model Amanda Wall. He splits his time between Los Angeles and Paris.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/2013/02/olivier-zahm-fashions-most-libidinal-editor.html|title=Riding Around Paris With Olivier Zahm, Fashion’s Most Libidinal Editor|work=The Cut|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessoffashion.com/community/people/olivier-zahm|title=Olivier Zahmis One of the 500 People Shaping the Global Fashion Industry|work=The Business of Fashion|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-GB}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.purple-diary.com purple DIARY] * [http://www.purple.fr/ Purple’s website] * [http://www.jedroot.com/photographers/olivier-zahm Olivier Zahm's profile at Jed Root] * [http://sgustok.org/art/olivier-zahm Olivier Zahm on Sgustok Magazine] * [http://nymag.com/thecut/2013/02/olivier-zahm-fashions-most-libidinal-editor.html Riding Around Paris With Olivier Zahm, Fashion’s Most Libidinal Editor] * revision.text:
[[File:Svedomskiy-portrait.jpg|thumb|175px|Pavel Svedomsky
(date unknown)]] '''Pavel Aleksandrovich Svedomsky''' ({{lang-ru|Павел Александрович Сведомский}}; 7 June 1849, [[Saint-Petersburg]]—27 August 1904, [[Rome]]) was a Russian painter and the brother of another artist, [[Alexander Svedomsky]]. Pavel Svedomsky studied first in the [[Düsseldorf]] Academy of Arts, then in [[Munich]] under [[Eduard von Gebhardt]] and [[Mihály Munkácsy]]. ==Life== [[File:Svedomsky-Fulvia.jpg|thumb|350px|''[[Fulvia]] With the Head of [[Cicero]]'']] Svedomsky belonged to hereditary [[Russian nobility]]. Together with his brother he spent the childhood in the family estate Mikhaylovski Zavod, located in the [[Perm]] [[Guberniya]]. In 1870 Pavel entered the Düsseldorf Academy of Arts, but studied there only few months. The Svedomskys traveled together across Europe until settling in Rome in 1875. He died there in 1904 and is buried with his brother Alexander in the [[Protestant Cemetery, Rome|Protestant Cemetery]].[http://www.protestantcemetery.it/graves/databases.html Non-Catholic Cemetery in Rome databases: Swedomsky Paolo] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130207015655/http://www.protestantcemetery.it/graves/databases.html |date=February 7, 2013 }} Pavel Svedomsky painted in various genres, most notably in historic. The painting ''Medusa'' (1882) was bought by [[Pavel Tretyakov]] to be displayed in [[Tretyakov Gallery]].{{ru icon}} [http://diaghilev.u-education.ru/svedom/content/files/page5.html# СВЕДОМСКИЙ ПАВЕЛ АЛЕКСАНДРОВИЧ] Diaghilev.u-education.ru Working in the [[St Volodymyr's Cathedral]] in [[Kiev]], Svedosmky painted the northern and southern [[nave]]s of the cathedral, creating six scenes from the life of [[Jesus]]: ''The Resurrection of [[Lazarus of Bethany|Lazarus]]'', ''The Entry of Christ into Jerusalem'', ''The [[Last Supper]]'', ''The [[Agony in the Garden]]'', ''The Trial of [[Pontius Pilate|Pilate]]'', ''The Crucifixion'' and ''The Ascension''.{{ru icon}} [http://www.rulex.ru/01180056.htm Сведомские (художники)] Rulex.ru During his later years Svedomsky turned to Russian subjects, painting ''The Poor Bride'', ''The Fool in Christ'', ''The Fire of Moscow, 1812'' (1879) and ''The Execution of [[Yermak]]''. The works of Svedomsky are scattered across various central and regional museums. The Tretyakov Gallery houses five of his paintings, while the Perm State Art Gallery holds a sketch for the church painting ''Procession of the Cross'', as well as ''Two Roman Women With Tambourine and Flute''. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Pavel Svedomsky}} *[http://www.vlsobor.com/author_7.html?lang_en Biography] @ the St.Volodymyr's Cathedral website {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Svedomsky, Pavel}} [[Category:19th-century Russian painters]] [[Category:Russian male painters]] [[Category:20th-century Russian painters]] [[Category:Christian artists]] [[Category:1849 births]] [[Category:1904 deaths]] [[Category:People from Saint Petersburg]] [[Category:Burials in the Protestant Cemetery, Rome]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Theatre |name = Smock Alley Theatre |image = RpDUB (30333174562) (fix).jpg |caption = |address = 6/7 Exchange Street Lower |city = [[Dublin|Dublin 8]] |country = [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] |pushpin_map = Ireland Central Dublin |coordinates = {{coord|53.345068|N|6.2695543|W|type:landmark|display=inline}} |architect = |owner = |capacity = |type = [[Theater (structure)|theatre]] |opened = 2012 |yearsactive = 2012 to present |rebuilt = |closed = |othernames = |production = |currentuse = |website = {{URL|smockalley.com}} }} [[File:RpDUB (30333529542).jpg|thumb|Main stage]] [[File:Smock Alley Theatre Dublin sign.JPG|thumb|Smock Alley Theatre sign]]
Since the 17th century there have been numerous theatres in Dublin with the name of '''Smock Alley'''.
The current '''Smock Alley Theatre''' is a 21st-century theatre in Dublin, converted from a 19th-century church building, incorporating structural material from an 18th-century theatre building, and built on the site of the 17th century [[Theatre Royal, Dublin]]. The present theatre was opened in 2012, after a €3.5 million investment.<ref>[http://www.thejournal.ie/smock-alley-theatre-reopening-after-225-years-453466-May2012/ Smock Alley Theatre reopening after 225 years - New theatre set to open today on site of original facility which opened in 1662.] 17 May 2012</ref>
The Smock Alley Theatre site comprises Smock Alley Theatre (178 seats), The Boys School (60 - 100 capacity), Black Box (80 capacity), and The Banquet Hall (300 capacity).
==History of the building== ===Theatre Royal===
The first Theatre Royal was opened on the site by [[John Ogilby]] in 1662. Ogilby, who was the first Irish [[Master of the Revels]], had previously run the [[Werburgh Street Theatre|New Theatre]] in [[Werburgh Street]], which had closed during the Puritan [[Commonwealth of England|interregnum]]. This building was entirely demolished, with a new theatre replacing it in 1735. This second building was active as a theatre until 1759, with a brief later revival until its final closure in 1787.
====First building (1662)==== The Theatre Royal consisted of a classical proscenium stage, pit, boxes, a middle and upper gallery, lattices (which were a type of box peculiar to Dublin) and a music/orchestra loft above the stage, also the acoustics were said to be excellent. The pit had backless benches and a raked floor that rose toward the back of the audience to help sightlines. Mostly single men sat here, and it was the noisiest, rowdiest area in the theatre. Boxes sat upper-class aristocrats. Boxes were luxuriously decorated with velvet drapes should the occupants require some privacy during the evening....for whatever reason. The doors were wider in the boxes to allow access for the voluminous dresses of the ladies. Galleries held the lower class, including servants of the upper classes in attendance. These were the worst seats as they were on the same level as the large chandeliers that lit the theatre. Candles were made of tallow (animal fat) and they were very pungent and smokey. The building was built on reclaimed ground from the River Liffey and due to this, in 1670 and later in 1701 the upper galleries collapsed killing several people inside and injuring many more including the son of the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, Charles Earl of Middlesex. He was pulled from the wreckage of his box with two broken legs
There was another partial collapse in March 1734 after which it was abandoned for a short while. The major decision was then taken to demolish and rebuild the theatre in 1735 with increased audience capacity.
====Second building (1735)==== In the time between the demolition of the original theatre and the construction of its replacement, a new theatre had opened in Aungier Street and it managed to wrestle the title Theatre Royal from Smock Alley for a time. In 1745 Thomas Sheridan, godson of [[Jonathan Swift]], took on the role of manager of Smock Alley and Aungier Street. He made many improvements and reclaimed the title Theatre Royal for Smock Alley. By 1750 the Aungier Street theatre had closed down. Sheridan was not only director of the theatre, he was also a playwright and strove to improve audiences at the theatre by cleaning up the neighbourhood in which it stood. At the time there were many unsavoury taverns and ale houses as well as many establishments of ill repute that Sheridan successfully petitioned to have closed down in favour of more wholesome and decent businesses. This change in the area encouraged more noble people to again return to the theatre and it once again thrived.
[[Benjamin Victor (theatre manager)|Benjamin Victor]] was an Englishman who originally visited Ireland in an effort to extend his textile business, but that did not prove profitable, and he eventually gave it up. On 11 October 1746 Victor settled with his family in Dublin as treasurer and deputy-manager to Sheridan at the Smock Alley Theatre. The theatre was for some years fairly successful; but about 1753 Sheridan was at variance with a portion of the theatre-going public, and for two years Victor and John Sowdon, a principal actor in the company, took over its management. On 15 July 1755 Sheridan returned to Dublin, and Victor resumed his old position. Eventually the theatre was closed on 20 April 1759, and Victor returned to England. The theatre later reopened, being active until 1787, but Victor did not return - having become involved with the [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane|Drury Lane Theatre]] in his native London.
====Legacy==== The first Theatre Royal housed the plays of [[George Farquhar]] (The Recruiting Officer/The Beaux Stratagem), [[Oliver Goldsmith]] (She Stoops to Conquer) and [[Richard Brinsley Sheridan]], son of Thomas Sheridan (The Rivals/School for Scandal). It was here that the stars of world theatre appeared to much acclaim such as Peg Woffington, Thomas Sheridan, Spranger Barry and Charles Macklin. It was on the stage of Smock Alley Theatre that [[David Garrick]], the greatest actor of the 18th century, first played Hamlet. It was the first time Hamlet had ever been staged in Ireland and some 3,000 customer clambered to get one of only 300 tickets.
It was also the site of some infamous 18th century Dublin riots, the most serious being the Kelly riots of 1747. Thomas Sheridan was manager at the time and had recently banned the presence of audience members on stage and the taking of money for the privilege of going backstage. These rules were for men only. Indeed, it was under Charles II that the law was changed to even allow women to act on stage. These rules were severely tested by a very drunk Trinity College student named Richard Kelly. Kelly did not appreciate the new rules restricting access backstage and brazenly went back stage.<ref name=Chronology>{{cite book|editor=Moody, T. W.|title=A New History of Ireland. '''8''': A Chronology of Irish History|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1989|isbn=978-0-19-821744-2|display-editors=etal}}</ref>
===St Michael and John's Church (1815)===
In 1758 another rival theatre opened, and eventually the Theatre Royal at Smock Alley closed in 1787. After this, the building was used as a whiskey store, falling into heavy disrepair before purchase by Fr Michael Blake in 1811.
The structure of the derelict building was partially demolished, and the new church incorporated some of this original theatre structure into its own during the building work, which was carried out between 1811 and 1815. The resultant new building was named St Michael and John's Church, after the medieval churches of St Michael of the Hill (now Dublinia) and St John of Booth Street (Fishamble Street). It had a famous stained glass window that is now in Swords. The theatre still boasts ornate stained glass windows and ceiling plasterwork which dates from the turn of the 20th century.
When the bell tolled in 1811, 18 years before Catholic Emancipation; it was the first Catholic bell to ring in Dublin in nearly 300 years. This prompted the aldermen of the city to bring charges against Fr Blake, though these charges were dropped when young lawyer Daniel O'Connell came to his defence.
In 1989 due to falling numbers of parishioners the church of St Michael and John was deconsecrated. It was then redeveloped (part of the Temple Bar rejuvenation scheme) into the 'Viking Adventure' which was closed down in 2002.
===Excavation===
In 2009, a full archaeological excavation took place under Margaret Gowan Archaeology. The dig revealed part of the foundations from the first theatre on the site built in 1662, and the full basement and foundation plan of the 1735 theatre.
A total of 229 artefacts were recovered from the excavations, these included medieval and post-medieval pottery, glass finds (mostly wine bottles), clay tobacco pipe fragments, an actor's wig curler, a medieval roof tile, fragments of mosaic floor and lots of oyster shells, remnants of the building's theatrical past.
==References== {{reflist}} *Joseph Quincy Adams, quoting a contemporary manuscript source, in Shakespearean Playhouses: A History of English Theatres from the Beginnings to the Restoration, Boston, Houghton Mifflin, 1917; p. 419. *Simpson, L. (Margaret Gowen & Co. Ltd) Archaeological excavation at the Smock Alley Theatre 17/3/2010 *Dr. Christopher Morash (NUI Maynooth) Board Member of Smock Alley Ltd *Bynane, P. (Prof. Theatre, Texas Women's University) "As Good A Gentleman as You Are." The Kelly Riots at the Theatre Royal, Smock Alley *Joseph Quincy Adams, quoting a contemporary manuscript source, in Shakespearean Playhouses: A History of English Theatres from the Beginnings to the Restoration, Boston, Houghton Mifflin, 1917; p. 419.
==External links== *[http://smockalley.com/historical-cultural-building-dublin/ Smockalley website Our History]

revision.text:
{{Infobox architectural practice |name = Stanton Williams |architects = Alan Stanton
Paul Williams
Gavin Henderson
Patrick Richard[http://www.archiplanet.org/wiki/Stanton_Williams,_London,_England,_United_Kingdom Stanton Williams, London, England, United Kingdom], [http://www.archiplanet.org Archiplanet]. |city = London |founded = 1985 |significant_projects = [[University of the Arts London]] campus at King’s Cross; the [[Sainsbury Laboratory Cambridge University]]; the Britten Pears Archive in Aldeburgh; Hackney Marshes Centre; [[Eton Manor]] London 2012 Olympic, Paralympic and Legacy venue; King’s Cross Square; transformation of the [[Musée des Beaux-Arts de Nantes]]|}} '''Stanton Williams''' is a British [[architecture|architectural]] [[design]] practice based in [[Islington]], London. The studio was founded by Alan Stanton and Paul Williams in 1985 and now has a team of over 85 people with four directors, two associate directors and fifteen associates. Stanton Williams has completed over 350 architectural, urban design, masterplanning, exhibition and interior design projects, winning more than 100 awards. In 2012 their [[Sainsbury Laboratory Cambridge University|Sainsbury Laboratory]] in Cambridge was awarded the [[Stirling Prize]].{{cite web|last=Youngs|first=Ian|title=Sainsbury Laboratory wins Stirling architecture prize|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-19923820|publisher=BBC|accessdate=16 October 2012}} Paul Williams is the first design-trained architect to be registered with ARB and received an Honorary Doctorate from the University of the Arts London in 2012. Alan Stanton was elected a Royal Academician in 2009 and both Alan and Paul are both Royal Designers of Industry, [http://www.stantonwilliams.com Stanton Williams] They each received an OBE for their services to architecture in 2014.[http://www.stantonwilliams.com/news/alan-stanton-and-paul-williams-receive-obe-in-queens-2014-birthday-honours-list/ Alan Stanton and Paul Williams receive OBE in Queen's 2014 birthday honours list], [http://www.stantonwilliams.com/] The practice has developed its portfolio from an initial focus on museums and galleries towards a wide variety of projects, all of which demonstrate its overarching objective of putting the user’s experience of space, light and materials at the forefront of the agenda, as well as creating places that sensitively respond to their cultural, social and physical context. ==Projects== '''Current projects include:''' UCL East Marshgate, a new university campus in the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park; the [https://www.stantonwilliams.com/projects/royal-opera-house-open-up/ Royal Opera House's ‘Open Up' project]; a research building for [https://www.stantonwilliams.com/projects/zayed-centre-for-research-into-rare-disease-in-children/ Great Ormond Street Hospital]; and the [https://www.stantonwilliams.com/news/the-british-museums-albukhary-foundation-gallery-of-the-islamic-world-will-open-in-october/ British Museum's Albukhary Foundation Gallery of the Islamic World]. '''Recently completed projects include:''' [https://www.stantonwilliams.com/projects/cambridge-judge-business-school/ The Simon Sainsbury Centre at Cambridge Judge Business School]; and [https://www.stantonwilliams.com/projects/mus%C3%A9e-darts-de-nantes/ Musée d'arts de Nantes in France], one of the largest Fine Art museums outside Paris. '''Other notable projects include:''' The Stirling Prize-winning [https://www.stantonwilliams.com/projects/sainsbury-laboratory/ Sainsbury Laboratory] in Cambridge; [https://www.stantonwilliams.com/projects/tintagel-house/ Tintagel House] in Vauxhall; [https://www.stantonwilliams.com/projects/victoria-hall-kings-cross/ Victoria Hall King's Cross]; [https://www.stantonwilliams.com/projects/compton-verney-art-gallery/ Compton Verney Art Gallery]; and [https://www.stantonwilliams.com/projects/london-2012-olympics-eton-manor/ Eton Manor,] designed for the London 2012 Olympics. ==Publications== ''A Walk Around King’s Cross: Volume 1''
Ed. Ruth Slavid
The Architect’s Journal / EMAP publishing, 2014 [http://www.waterstones.com/waterstonesweb/products/ruth+slavid/a+walk+around+king27s+cross/10846763/Waterstones Books], [http://www.waterstones.com/] ''The Sainsbury Laboratory: Science, Architecture, Art''
Stephen Day, John Parker, Steve Rose
Black Dog Publishing, Year 2011 [http://www.artificebooksonline.com/ARTIFICE_WEB/Buiding_Studies_and_Monographs.html artifice books, Building Studies and Monographs], [http://www.artificebooksonline.com/] ''Stanton Williams: Volume''
Stephen Bayley, Irenee Scalbert, David Taylor
Black Dog Publishing, 2009 [http://www.artificebooksonline.com/ARTIFICE_WEB/Buiding_Studies_and_Monographs.html artifice books, Building Studies and Monographs], [http://www.artificebooksonline.com/] ''Stanton Williams''
''De aedibus international Volume 1''
Ed. Heinz Wirzn
Quart Verlag, 2009 [http://www.quart.ch/de-aedibus-international-en.php?nID=317 Quart Architektur, De aedibus international], [http://www.quart.ch/index.php] ==Teaching, lectures and mentoring== A number of Stanton Williams’ architects and designers are teachers, guest lecturers and external examiners at schools of architecture and creative arts universities. The Directors have acted as external examiners at Westminster, Plymouth, Dundee, Birmingham Schools of Architecture, the Architectural Association, Kingston University, University of East London, Oxford Brookes University, Glasgow School of Art and University of Greenwich. They have held teaching and visiting critic roles at London Metropolitan University, Westminster University, Central Saint Martins MA Creative Practice for Narrative Environments and the Ecole Polytechnique de Lausanne in Switzerland. Alan Stanton is a trustee of Open-City.[http://open-city.org.uk/contact/index.html Open City Trustees], [http://open-city.org.uk/index.html] Paul Williams is an advisor to the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and St Paul’s Cathedral. He is a trustee of Space Studios [http://www.spacestudios.org.uk/about/trustees-advisors/ Space Studio Trustees], [http://www.spacestudios.org.uk/] and also sits on the RIBA Public Education Committee.[https://www.architecture.com/RIBA/Aboutus/Whoweare/RIBABoard.aspx RIBA Education Committee], [https://www.architecture.com/RIBA/Home.aspx] The practice supports the Open-City Education Fund, and takes part in Open-City’s architectural education programmes ‘Architecture in Schools’ and ‘Accelerate into University’.[http://open-city.org.uk/getinvolved/sponsorship.html Open City Supporters], [http://open-city.org.uk/index.html] Stanton Williams offers support and mentoring to architectural students at Central Saint Martins (via the RIBA London Student Mentoring scheme), University of Greenwich, University of East London and the Bartlett School of Architecture. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.stantonwilliams.com/ Stanton Williams website] {{Stirling Prize laureates}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Architecture firms based in London]] [[Category:Stirling Prize laureates]] [[Category:Design companies established in 1985]] [[Category:1985 establishments in England]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Swanke Hayden Connell Architects | logo = Swanke Hayden Connell Architects logo.png | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | traded_as = | industry = [[Architecture]] | foundation = {{Start date and age|1909}} | defunct = {{End date and age|2015}} | founder = Alexander Stewart Walker
Leon N. Gillette | location = | location_city = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | location_country = [[United States]] | key_people = | area_served = Worldwide | products = | num_employees = | homepage = {{URL|www.shca.com}} }} '''Swanke Hayden Connell Architects''' was an international architecture, interiors and historic preservation firm with U.S. headquarters in [[New York City]]. ==History== The firm was founded in New York in 1906 by Alexander Stewart Walker (1876-1952) and Leon N. Gillette (1878-1945). Originally known as [[Walker & Gillette]], the firm designed country estates and urban townhouses for some of New York's more affluent families.{{cite journal|last=Covell|first=Alwyn T.|title=Works of Walker & Gillette (Variety in Architectural Practice)|journal=Architectural Record|date=January–June 1914|volume=XXXV|pages=277–355}} Through the years, the practice expanded to include corporate interiors for prominent banking and brokerage concerns as well as major architectural commissions such as the [[Fuller Building]] at 57th Street and Madison Avenue and the First National Bank Building at 57th Street. Following Gillette's death in 1945,{{cite news|title=L.N. Gillette Dies; Long an Architect|newspaper=The New York Times|date=May 4, 1945}} A. Stewart Walker merged his practice with the Office of [[Alfred Easton Poor]]. The firm practiced under the name of Walker & Poor from 1946 to 1952 with commissions that included Sotheby Parke Bernet Galleries, [[Chemical Bank]], [[Morgan Stanley]] & Co. Inc., [[Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation]] and [[NATO]] air bases in France. After Walker's death in 1952,{{cite news|title=A. Stewart Walker, Noted Architect, 72|newspaper=The New York Times|date=June 11, 1952}} the firm continued the practice as the Office of Alfred Easton Poor until 1971. In 1958, the firm opened a second office in Washington, D.C. During this period, the firm expanded and diversified further into governmental facilities, office buildings, communications centers, and industrial structures throughout the United States, Europe, and South America. In 1972, the firm became known as Poor and Swanke & Partners, in 1975, Poor, Swanke, Hayden & Connell, in 1979, Swanke Hayden Connell & Partners, and in 1981, Swanke Hayden Connell Architects. During this time, the firm expanded its disciplines and became a global practice, opening offices in Miami and London in 1987, Istanbul in 1997, Sheffield 2002, Moscow in 2006, and Shanghai in 2010. In 2000, the firm acquired Taylor Clark Architects,{{cite web|title=Richard C. Clark, architect|url=http://www.allbusiness.com/operations/facilities-commercial-real-estate/753794-1.html}} a firm specializing in the healthcare field. In 2002, the Firm acquired George Trew Dunn Architects,{{cite news|title=Swanke Hayden acquires firm|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m3601/is_39_48/ai_86851793/?tag=content;col1|newspaper=Real Estate Weekly|date=May 1, 2002}} another healthcare architecture firm with offices in London and Sheffield, England. On January 6, 2015 the firm filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, after failing to receive over $2 million in fees from a client.{{cite web|title=Century-old architecture firm Swanke Hayden Connell files for bankruptcy|url=http://www.dezeen.com/2015/01/14/swanke-hayden-connell-architects-bankruptcy/}} ==Notable buildings== * [[Trump Tower]], New York, New York, 1983 *[[Continental Center (New York City)|Continental Center]], 1983 * [[Statue of Liberty]] Restoration, [[Liberty Island]], New York, New York, 1986 * 4 Columbus Circle, New York, New York, 1989 * [[Americas Tower]] (1177 Avenue of the Americas), New York, New York, 1991 * FDNY Training Center, [[Randall's Island]], New York, 2003 * [[West Virginia State Capitol]] Dome Restoration, Charleston, West Virginia, 2005 * [[New York City Office of Emergency Management]], Brooklyn, New York, 2006 * Nassau County Public Safety Center, Westbury, New York, 2011 * [[Eurasia (building)|Eurasia Tower]], Moscow * Tower 45, New York, New York, 1989 *[[Tekfen Tower]], Istanbul, 2002 == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.shca.com/}} [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Architecture firms of the United States]] [[Category:Architecture firms based in New York City]] [[Category:Preservationist architects]] [[Category:Design companies established in 1906]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = The Excursion to Tilsit | image = | image_caption = | author = [[Hermann Sudermann]] | title_orig = Litauische Geschichten | translator = Lewis Galantière | country = Germany | language = German | publisher = J.G. Cotta | pub_date = 1917 | english_pub_date = 1930 | pages = 488 }} '''''The Excursion to Tilsit''''' is a 1917 collection of short stories or novellas by the German writer [[Hermann Sudermann]]. Its German title is '''''Litauische Geschichten''''', which means "Lithuanian stories". The book consists of four stories set in rural Lithuania in the mid 19th century. It was published in English in 1930, translated by Lewis Galantière.{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/excursion-to-tilsit/oclc/1474999|title=The excursion to Tilsit|work=[[WorldCat]]|accessdate=2015-09-25}} Several stories from the book have been adapted for film. Most famously, [[F. W. Murnau]]'s 1927 film ''[[Sunrise: A Song of Two Humans]]'' is loosely based on the titular story.{{Cite book|last=Fischer|first=Lucy|year=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V96tee1l2q8C&pg=PA75|chapter=Sunrise: A Tale of Two Humans|editor1-last=White|editor1-first=Rob|editor2-last=Buscombe|editor2-first=Edward|title=British Film Institute Film Classics, Volume 1|location=London; New York|publisher=[[British Film Institute]]; [[Fitzroy Dearborn Publishers|Fitzroy Dearborn]]|page=75|isbn=1-57958-328-8}} ==Stories and plots== '''The Excursion to Tilsit''' (Die Reise nach Tilsit)
A married man is in love with his mistress and plans to drown his wife on the way back from a trip to [[Sovetsk, Kaliningrad Oblast|Tilsit]]. During the trip he reconciles with his wife, changes his mind and tells her about his now abandoned plan. In a fatal accident the man drowns and the wife is saved through the means the man had prepared for his own escape.
'''Miks Bumbullis'''
A murderer needs to visit the grave of his daughter to please the goddess of death, despite knowing that the police will be there waiting for him.
'''Jons and Erdma''' (Jons und Erdme)
A couple become wealthy by the means of tricks and foul play. Eventually they are in turn tricked by their daughters and have to start again from zero.
'''The Hired Girl''' (Die Magd) ==Reception== Margaret Wallace of ''[[The Bookman (New York)|The Bookman]]'' wrote:
Like [[Selma Lagerlöf]], and many other novelists whose material is national and even provincial, Sudermann by his very unconcern with cosmopolitan values gives a deeper truth and meaning to the lives of his characters. Of these four stories of Lithuanian peasants, only one, "Miks Bumbullis", depends for its effect upon purely national traits and circumstances. They are, for the most part, founded solidly upon the fundamental and inescapable human facts of birth and love and death. They are moving and tragic and, above all, intensely and vividly alive.{{Cite web|last=Wallace|first=Margaret|year=April 1930|url=http://www.unz.org/Pub/Bookman-1930apr-00214a03|title=''The Excursion to Tilsit'' by Hermann Sudermann|work=[[The Bookman (New York)|The Bookman]]|page=214-215}}
''[[The Outlook (New York)|The Outlook]]'' reviewed the book:
''Excursion to Tilsit'' by Hermann Sudermann is a collection of powerful short stories dealing with the life of Lithuanian peasants. The author has observed them sympathetically and at first hand. Nominal Catholics, they still live in fear of pagan gods, giving even their lives to propitiate them. ... Among the stories, that of Jons and Erdma who, having built a home by tricks and cunning are tricked out of it at last by their daughters, compares favorably with [[Ivan Turgenev|Turgeniev's]] ''Lear of the Steppes'' as a story of faith and treachery.{{Cite web|date=1930-04-02|url=http://www.unz.org/Pub/Outlook-1930apr02-00544a02|title=The Leisure Arts: The Week's Reading|work=[[The Outlook (New York)|The Outlook]]|page=546}}
==Film adaptations== * ''[[Sunrise: A Song of Two Humans]]'', 1927, directed by [[F. W. Murnau]] * ''[[The Journey to Tilsit]]'', 1939, directed by [[Veit Harlan]] * ''[[Jons und Erdme]]'', 1959, directed by [[Victor Vicas]] * ''Reise nach Tilsit'', 1969, TV film, directed by Günter Gräwert * ''Miks Bumbullis'', 1971, TV film, directed by Günter Gräwert * ''The Excursion to Paradise'', 1980, directed by Arūnas Žebriūnas ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://archive.org/details/litauischegeschi00sudeuoft ''Litauische Geschichten''] at [[Internet Archive]] {{De icon}} * [http://gutenberg.spiegel.de/buch/die-reise-nach-tilsit-1984/1 Die Reise nach Tilsit] at [[Projekt Gutenberg-DE]] {{De icon}} * [http://gutenberg.spiegel.de/buch/miks-bumbullis-1986/1 Miks Bumbullis] at Projekt Gutenberg-DE {{De icon}} * [http://gutenberg.spiegel.de/buch/jons-und-erdme-1992/1 Jons und Erdme] at Projekt Gutenberg-DE {{De icon}} * [http://gutenberg.spiegel.de/buch/die-magd-1990/1 Die Magd] at Projekt Gutenberg-DE {{De icon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Excursion to Tilsit}} [[Category:1917 short story collections]] [[Category:Books adapted into films]] [[Category:German short story collections]] [[Category:German-language literature]] [[Category:Lithuania in fiction]] [[Category:Works by Hermann Sudermann]]
